title: On pro-cdh descent on derived schemes

sections.text:
#### Abstract

We prove a 'pro-cdh descent' result for suitably connective localizing invariants and the cotangent complex on arbitrary qcqs derived schemes. As an application, we deduce that the $K$-groups of arbitrary qcqs schemes vanish below the negative of their valuative dimension.

## CONTENTS

1. Introduction 1
2. Preliminaries on derived algebraic geometry 5
3. Modifications of derived schemes 11
4. Pro-cdh descent for connective localizing invariants 13
5. Pro-cdh descent for the cotangent complex and motivic cohomology 18
6. Generalized Weibel vanishing 21

References 30

## 1. Introduction

The algebraic $K$-groups of a blowup $\mathrm{Bl}_{Z}(X)$ of a quasi-compact, quasi-separated (qcqs, for short) scheme $X$ in a regularly immersed center $Z$ have been computed by Thomason [Tho93] (see also [CHSW08, Prop. 1.5]). In particular, the blowup square
![img-0.jpeg](img-0.jpeg)
gives rise to a cartesian square of algebraic $K$-theory spectra and hence to a long exact sequence of algebraic $K$-groups. If the closed immersion $Z \hookrightarrow X$ is not regular, this will fail in general. However, if $X$ is Noetherian, and one takes infinitesimal information into account, one still gets a cartesian square. More precisely, if $Z(n)$ and $E(n)$ denote the $n$-th

infinitesimal thickenings of $Z$ in $X$ and $E$ in $\operatorname{Bl}_{Z}(X)$, respectively, the square of pro-spectra
![img-1.jpeg](img-1.jpeg)
is weakly cartesian and hence induces a long exact sequence of pro-abelian groups. Note here that the pro-systems only depend on the underlying topological space of $Z$ (and $E$ ) as a closed subset of $X$ (and $\operatorname{Bl}_{Z}(X)$, respectively) but not on the particular subscheme structure. In fact, more generally any abstract blowup square of Noetherian schemes gives rise to a weakly cartesian square of $K$-theory pro-spectra. In this form, this result, often coined "pro-cdh descent", ${ }^{1}$ is first proven in [KST18], but there are important precursors [KS02, Cor06, Kri10, GH06, GH11, Mor16b, Mor18]. A variant for Noetherian ANS stacks has been considered in [BKRS22]. These pro-cdh descent results play a central role in the resolution of Weibel's $K$-dimension conjecture [KST18] (and [BKRS22] for stacks) and the development of a continuous $K$-theory of rigid spaces [Mor16a, KST19, KST23].

Given the rising interest in non-Noetherian schemes, which appear naturally, for example, when working over a perfectoid base ring such as $\mathcal{O}_{\mathbb{C}_{p}}$, it is an obvious question, whether, or in which form, pro-cdh descent also holds in this general setting. The following example, a variant of which was constructed by Dahlhausen and the third author [DT22] precisely for that purpose and which was independently studied by the first two authors [Kel24, Footnote 2] with respect to the pro-cdh topology, shows that pro-cdh descent as formulated above does not hold for general abstract blowup squares of non-Noetherian schemes.

Example 1.1. Let $R$ be a valuation ring of dimension at least 2. Let $0 \subsetneq \mathfrak{p} \subsetneq \mathfrak{m}$ be prime ideals in $R$, and choose $x \in \mathfrak{m} \backslash \mathfrak{p}$ and $y \in \mathfrak{p} \backslash\{0\}$. Then $x^{n}$ divides $y$ for all $n \geq 1$ and for each $n$ the square
![img-2.jpeg](img-2.jpeg)
is an abstract blowup square. If the induced square of $K$-theory pro-spectra would be weakly cartesian, the map $K(R /(x y)) \rightarrow K(R /(y))$ would be an equivalence. However, as $y^{2}=0$ in $R /(x y), 1+y$ is a unit and defines a non-trivial element in the kernel of $K_{1}(R /(x y)) \rightarrow$ $K_{1}(R /(y))$.

A posteriori, this is not surprising: A key point in [KST18] was to prove Thomason's blowup formula for derived blowups in quasi-smooth centers together with the fact that for every closed subscheme of an affine Noetherian scheme there exists a quasi-smooth derived closed subscheme with the same underlying classical scheme. The condition that all (derived) rings and schemes appearing be Noetherian then allowed to pass from derived schemes back to classical schemes. For instance, for a Noetherian commutative ring $A$ and elements $f_{1}, \ldots, f_{r}$ in $A$ generating the ideal $I \subseteq A$, the pro-system of (Koszul type) derived quotients

[^0]
[^0]:    ${ }^{1}$ We remark that it would be more appropriate to call this "pro-cdh excision" since it is not precisely a descent statement for some topology. However, together with Nisnevich excision, it does imply actual (Čech) descent for the pro-cdh topology of [KS24], see Theorem 6.1 there. For this reason, and to be in line with the existing literature we stick to the term "pro-cdh descent."

$\left\{A \nless f_{1}^{n}, \ldots, f_{r}^{n}\right\}_{n}$ is equivalent to the pro-system of discrete rings $\left\{A / I^{n}\right\}_{n}$. This suggested that some variant of the above pro-cdh descent statement, where one takes "derived" infinitesimal thickenings everywhere, could still be true. This is precisely what we achieve in this paper. Our main $K$-theoretic result is the following.

Theorem A. Let $f: Y \rightarrow X$ be a proper, locally almost finitely presented morphism of qcqs derived schemes which is an isomorphism outside a closed subset $Z \subseteq|X|$ whose open complement is quasi-compact. Denote by $X_{Z}^{\wedge}$ and $Y_{Z}^{\wedge}$ the formal completion of $X$ (respectively $Y$ ) along $Z$ (respectively $f^{-1}(Z)$ ) viewed as ind-derived schemes. Then the square of prospectra
![img-3.jpeg](img-3.jpeg)
is weakly cartesian.
Let us point out that this result is not specific to $K$-theory. It holds more generally for every localising invariant which is $k$-connective in the sense of [LT19] for some integer $k$; see Theorem 4.6 for the general statement. For instance, it also applies to THH, TC, and rational negative cyclic homology.

Remark 1.2. One may ask whether the same statement also holds for spectral schemes. As our proof makes essential use of the theory of derived blowups of derived schemes developed by Khan and Rydh [KR18], we cannot treat this more general case with our methods.

We also prove the analogous result for the cotangent complex, see Theorem 5.4. By the arguments of [EM23] one then obtains pro-cdh descent in the above form for motivic cohomology (Corollary 5.5). We thank Matthew Morrow for suggesting this result for the cotangent complex and indicating the application to motivic cohomology.

In [KST18], pro-cdh descent of $K$-theory was used to derive Weibel's conjecture on the vanishing of negative $K$-groups of a Noetherian scheme $X$ below $-\operatorname{dim}(X)$. It is an obvious question what we can say about negative $K$-groups if we merely assume $X$ to be qcqs; see e.g. Morrow's Oberwolfach talk [Mor23]. As the Krull dimension doesn't have good properties for general non-Noetherian schemes, one might expect that instead the valuative dimension introduced by Jaffard [Jaff60] (see [EHIK20] or [KS24, §7.1] for accounts) gives the correct bounds. It coincides with the Krull dimension if $X$ is Noetherian. Indeed, we prove the following.

Theorem B (Theorem 6.5). Let $X$ be a qcqs spectral scheme. Then the following hold.
(1) $K_{-i}(X)=0$ for all $i>\operatorname{vdim}(X)$.
(2) For all $i \geq \operatorname{vdim}(X)$ and any integer $r \geq 0$, the pullback map $K_{-i}(X) \rightarrow K_{-i}\left(\mathbb{A}_{X}^{r}\right)$ is an isomorphism. In other words, $X$ is $K_{-\operatorname{vdim}(X)}$-regular.

Here by a spectral scheme we mean more precisely one with connective structure sheaf, and in (2), $\mathbb{A}^{r}$ denotes either the flat or the smooth affine space.

Remark 1.3. We don't know an example of a scheme $X$ with $\operatorname{vdim}(X)>\operatorname{dim}(X)$ and $K_{-\operatorname{vdim}(X)}(X) \neq 0$

This theorem immediately implies the same vanishing for Weibel's homotopy $K$-theory $K H(X)$. In other words, we get a new proof of assertion (1) in the following theorem, which we include here for the sake of completeness. As we discuss below, this theorem is well known to the experts. We write $L_{\text {cdh }}$ for the cdh sheafification functor on presheaves of spectra and $K_{\geq 0}$ for the presheaf of connective algebraic $K$-theory.

Theorem 1.4. Let $X$ be a qcqs scheme of finite valuative dimension.
(1) $K H_{-i}(X)=0$ for all $i>\operatorname{vdim}(X)$.
(2) The natural maps $L_{\mathrm{cdh}} K_{\geq 0} \rightarrow L_{\mathrm{cdh}} K \rightarrow K H$ are equivalences.

For schemes essentially of finite type over a field of characteristic 0 , this was first proven in [Hae04]. For general Noetherian $X$, (1) was first proven in [KS17] and (2) in [KST18]. The fact that $K H$ is a cdh sheaf is [Cis13]. In the general case, the theorem follows easily from recent results on the cdh-topology [EHIK20] and the $K$-theory of valuation rings [KM21, KST21]. In fact, the proof given under Noetherian assumptions in [KM21] still works, and for the reader's convenience we reproduce this proof at the end of the paper. Alternatively, the proof of [KS17] respectively [KST18] works mutatis mutandis, using the fact that a blowup does not increase the valuative dimension (this is not necessarily true for the Krull dimension).

Remark 1.5. For arbitrary qcqs schemes $X$, Theorem 1.4 together with the cartesian square
![img-4.jpeg](img-4.jpeg)
$(-1)$-connectivity of topological cyclic homology on affines, and [EHIK20] imply the slightly weaker vanishing $K_{-i}(X)=0$ for $i>\operatorname{vdim}(X)+2$. Elmanto and Morrow (over fields) and Bouis (in general) prove refinements of this for the motivic filtration [EM23, Proof of Thm. 4.12], [Bou24, Prop. 5.5.4].

Structure of the arguments and the paper. The proof of Theorem A follows the outline of [KST18], but requires substantially more input from derived geometry. It is reduced to the two special cases of derived blowups and finite morphisms, respectively. This reduction is achieved by a structural result about modifications of derived schemes, Theorem 3.2, which we view as our main contribution here. In its proof, we need several preliminary results from derived algebraic geometry which we discuss in Section 2.

The case of Theorem A for derived blowups could essentially be proved as in [KST18]. We here present a stronger result with a simplified proof due to Antieau ([Ant18]; we reproduce his proof in Proposition 4.1). For the case of finite morphisms in Theorem A, compared to [KST18] we give a simple proof of a more general result (Proposition 4.2).

To prove Theorem B in Section 6, we roughly follow Kerz's approach [Ker18] combined with our pro-cdh-descent for finite morphisms. Another new input is a generalization of results of Swanson and Huneke [HS06] on reductions of ideals to the non-Noetherian setting in Subsection 6.2.

Related work. Another approach to pro-cdh descent statements has been proposed by Clausen and Scholze. It is based on condensed mathematics [Sch] and Efimov's theory of localizing invariants of large categories [Efi24].

In forthcoming work, the first two authors introduce a "pro-cdh topology" on qcqs derived schemes. It will follow from Theorem A (or 4.6) that every localizing invariant which is $k$-connective for some integer $k$ satisfies descent for that topology.

Acknowledgement. We thank Christian Dahlhausen for discussions about pro-cdh descent in the non-Noetherian setting which led to the variant of Example 1.1 and which was one of the starting points of this project. We are grateful to Ben Antieau for allowing us to include his pro-excision result for derived blowups, which is stronger than the one obtained in [KST18]. We thank Matthew Morrow for bringing our attention to the cotangent complex and further comments and Mauro Porta for related discussions. Finally we thank David Rydh for enlightening comments on our Sections 2 and 3. In particular, he proposed to formulate the more precise version of Theorem 3.2 including different finiteness hypotheses.

# 2. Preliminaries on Derived Algebraic Geometry 

We freely use the language of derived algebraic geometry as developed by Toën-Vezzosi [TV08, TV05], Lurie [Lur18] and others. The following subsections mainly serve to fix some notation and recall some notions and facts that will be used later on. Readers familiar with derived algebraic geometry may safely skip this section and only come back when needed.
2.1. Derived rings and schemes. We write $\mathrm{CAlg}^{\Delta}$ for the $\infty$-category of simplicial commutative rings $[\operatorname{Lur} 18, \S 25.1]$ and refer to its objects as derived rings. There is a forgetful functor $\mathrm{CAlg}^{\Delta} \rightarrow \mathrm{CAlg}^{\mathrm{cn}}$, where $\mathrm{CAlg}^{\mathrm{cn}}$ denotes the $\infty$-category of connective $\mathbb{E}_{\infty}$-algebras in spectra. This functor preserves small limits and colimits and is conservative.

A derived scheme is a pair $X=\left(|X|, \mathcal{O}_{X}\right)$ consisting of a topological space $|X|$ and a sheaf $\mathcal{O}_{X}$ of derived rings on $|X|$ such that ${ }^{\mathrm{cl}} X:=\left(|X|, \pi_{0} \mathcal{O}_{X}\right)$ is a classical scheme and the higher homotopy sheaves $\pi_{i} \mathcal{O}_{X}$ are quasi-coherent $\pi_{0} \mathcal{O}_{X}$-modules. We call ${ }^{\mathrm{cl}} X$ the underlying classical scheme or the classical truncation of $X$. Derived schemes form the objects of an $\infty$-category dSch, and similarly as above there is a forgetful functor from derived schemes to spectral schemes. There is also a functor of points approach to derived schemes. In other words, there is a fully faithful functor

$$
\mathrm{dSch} \rightarrow \operatorname{Fun}\left(\mathrm{CAlg}^{\Delta}, \mathrm{Spc}\right)
$$

which coincides with the Yoneda embedding on affine derived schemes [Lur18, §1.6].
A map $f: X \rightarrow Y$ of derived schemes is called proper, a closed immersion, affine, or finite, respectively, if the underlying map of classical schemes ${ }^{\mathrm{cl}} f$ has the corresponding property. If $U \subseteq|X|$ is an open subset, then $\left(U,\left.\mathcal{O}_{X}\right|_{U}\right)$ is itself a derived scheme. Such a derived scheme is called an open subscheme of $X$ which we simply denote by $U$.
2.2. Quasi-coherent modules. If $A$ is a derived ring, we write $\operatorname{Mod}(A)$ for the symmetric monoidal $\infty$-category of $A$-modules (in spectra). For a derived scheme $X$, we denote by $\operatorname{QCoh}(X)$ the category of quasi-coherent sheaves on $X$. These are stable $\infty$-categories with canonical t-structures, and we denote their connective part by $\operatorname{Mod}(A)^{\mathrm{cn}}$ and $\operatorname{QCoh}(X)^{\mathrm{cn}}$, respectively. Moreover, they only depend on the underlying spectrum or spectral scheme, respectively. If $X=\operatorname{Spec}(A)$ is affine, we have an equivalence $\operatorname{QCoh}(X)=\operatorname{Mod}(A)$.

If $Z \subseteq|X|$ is a closed subset, we denote by $\operatorname{QCoh}(X$ on $Z)$ the full subcategory of $\operatorname{QCoh}(X)$ spanned by those quasi-coherent sheaves which are supported on $Z$. If $X$ is quasi-compact and quasi-separated (qcqs, for short) and the open complement of $Z$ is quasi-compact, then $\operatorname{QCoh}(X$ on $Z)$ is compactly generated and its compact objects coincide with the perfect

ones, [Lur18, Prop. 9.6.1.1], [CMNN20, Prop. A.9]. Here a quasi-coherent sheaf on $X$ is called perfect if and only its restriction to each affine open subscheme $U=\operatorname{Spec}(A) \subseteq X$ belongs to the smallest thick stable subcategory of $\operatorname{QCoh}(U)=\operatorname{Mod}(A)$ containing $A$. We write $\operatorname{Perf}(X)$ and $\operatorname{Perf}(X$ on $Z)$ for the corresponding subcategories. The arguments used to prove this also apply to the case of connective sheaves:

Lemma 2.1. Let $X$ be a qcqs derived scheme, and let $Z \subseteq|X|$ be a closed subset with quasicompact open complement. Then $\operatorname{QCoh}(X$ on $Z)^{\mathrm{cn}}$ is compactly generated and the inclusion $\operatorname{QCoh}(X$ on $Z)^{\mathrm{cn}} \hookrightarrow \operatorname{QCoh}(X)^{\mathrm{cn}}$ preserves compact objects. An object of $\operatorname{QCoh}(X$ on $Z)^{\mathrm{cn}}$ is compact if and only if it is perfect (as an object of $\operatorname{QCoh}(X)$ ).

Proof. The same argument as in the proof of [CMNN20, Prop. A.9] proves the first two claims: In case $X$ is affine, these follow from [Lur18, Prop. 7.1.1.12(e)] and the fact that $\operatorname{QCoh}(X)^{\text {cn }}$ is compactly generated by [Lur18, Prop. 9.6.1.2]. The reduction of the global case to the local case is done by [Lur18, Ex. 10.3.0.2 (4), Prop. 10.3.0.3, Th. 10.3.2.1 (b)]. It then follows that an object of $\operatorname{QCoh}(X$ on $Z)^{\mathrm{cn}}$ is compact if and only if its image in $\operatorname{QCoh}(X)^{\mathrm{cn}}$ is compact. The compact objects in the latter category coincide with the perfect, connective $\mathcal{O}_{X}$-modules by [Lur18, Prop. 9.6.1.2.] again.
2.3. Free algebras. If $A$ is a derived ring, we denote the category of derived $A$-algebras by $\mathrm{CAlg}_{A}^{\Delta}$. Its objects are derived rings $B$ together with a map of derived rings $A \rightarrow B$. There is an obvious forgetful functor $\mathrm{CAlg}_{A}^{\Delta} \rightarrow \operatorname{Mod}(A)^{\mathrm{cn}}$ which admits a left adjoint, the free algebra functor, $\operatorname{LSym}_{A}^{\star}: \operatorname{Mod}(A)^{\mathrm{cn}} \rightarrow \operatorname{CAlg}_{A}^{\Delta}$. If $M$ is a connective $A$-module, the underlying $A$ module of $\operatorname{LSym}_{A}^{\star}(M)$ is the direct sum $\bigoplus_{n \geq 0} \operatorname{LSym}_{A}^{n}(M)$, where $\operatorname{LSym}_{A}^{n}(M)$ is the $n$-th derived symmetric power of $M$ as studied for instance by Quillen [Lur18, Constr. 25.2.2.6], whence the notation.

These constructions globalise: For a derived scheme $X$, write $\mathrm{CAlg}_{\mathcal{O}_{X}}^{\Delta}$ for the $\infty$-category of sheaves of derived rings on $|X|$ equipped with a map from $\mathcal{O}_{X}$ such that the underlying sheaf of $\mathcal{O}_{X}$-modules is quasi-coherent. There is an adjunction

$$
\operatorname{LSym}_{\mathcal{O}_{X}}^{\star}: \operatorname{QCoh}(X)^{\mathrm{cn}} \rightleftarrows \mathrm{CAlg}_{\mathcal{O}_{X}}^{\Delta}: \text { forget }
$$

the forgetful functor is conservative and preserves sifted colimits. Consequently, $\operatorname{LSym}_{\mathcal{O}_{X}}^{\star}$ sends compact objects to compact objects.

For $\mathcal{A} \in \operatorname{CAlg}_{\mathcal{O}_{X}}^{\Delta}$ one can form the relative spectrum $\operatorname{Spec}(\mathcal{A})$ which comes with an affine morphism $\operatorname{Spec}(\mathcal{A}) \rightarrow X$.
2.4. Finiteness conditions. A map of derived rings $A \rightarrow B$ is called locally of finite presentation if $B$ is a compact object of $\mathrm{CAlg}_{A}^{\Delta}$. It is called almost of finite presentation if $B$ is an almost compact object $\mathrm{CAlg}_{A}^{\Delta}$, i.e. each truncation $\tau_{\leq n} B$ is a compact object of $\tau_{\leq n} \mathrm{CAlg}_{A}^{\Delta}$; see [Lur04, §3.1] and [Lur18, §4.1] for the analog notions for $\mathbb{E}_{\infty}$-algebras. It turns out that $A \rightarrow B$ is almost of finite presentation if and only if the underlying map of $\mathbb{E}_{\infty}$-algebras is almost of finite presentation; the analog for being locally of finite presentation is wrong.

For completeness, we also mention that for an integer $n \geq 0$, there is a notion of finite generation to order $n$, see [Lur18, Def. 4.1.1.1], and a morphism is almost finitely presented if and only if it is of finite generation to order $n$ for all $n$.

These finiteness conditions are stable under base change: If $A \rightarrow B$ is locally or almost of finite presentation or of finite generation to order $n$ and $A \rightarrow A^{\prime}$ is an arbitrary map, then also $A^{\prime} \rightarrow B \otimes_{A} A^{\prime}$ is locally or almost of finite presentation or of finite generation to order

$n$, respectively [Lur17, Rem. 7.2.4.28], [Lur18, Prop. 4.1.3.2]. They are also stable under composition [Lur17, Rem. 7.2.4.29, Cor. 7.4.3.19], [Lur18, Prop. 4.1.3.1].

If $A$ is Noetherian, i.e. $\pi_{0}(A)$ is Noetherian in the classical sense and all higher homotopy groups are finitely generated $\pi_{0}(A)$-modules, then a derived $A$-algebra $B$ is almost of finite presentation if and only if $B$ is Noetherian and $\pi_{0}(B)$ is a classically finitely generated $\pi_{0}(A)$ algebra [Lur04, Prop. 3.1.5] or [Lur17, Prop. 7.2.4.31].

A map $f: Y \rightarrow X$ of derived schemes is called locally of finite presentation or locally almost of finite presentation (lafp, for short) if for all affine open subschemes $U=\operatorname{Spec}(A) \subseteq$ $X$ and $V=\operatorname{Spec}(B) \subseteq Y$ with $f(V) \subseteq U$ the induced morphism $A \rightarrow B$ is locally of finite presentation or almost of finite presentation, respectively. As in the affine case, these notions are stable under base change and composition, and there is a characterization in the Noetherian case.

For example, if $\mathcal{F}$ is a perfect, connective $\mathcal{O}_{X}$-module, i.e. a compact object of $\operatorname{QCoh}(X)^{\mathrm{cn}}$, then $\operatorname{Spec}\left(\operatorname{LSym}_{\mathcal{O}_{X}}^{*}(\mathcal{F})\right)$ is locally of finite presentation over $X$. Using this observation, we prove the following lemma.

Lemma 2.2. Let $X$ be a qcqs derived scheme, and let $U \subseteq X$ be a qc open subset with complement $Z$. Let $i: Y \rightarrow X$ be a closed immersion which is an isomorphism over $U$ and such that the underlying map of classical schemes ${ }^{\mathrm{cl}} Y \rightarrow{ }^{\mathrm{cl}} X$ is finitely presented. Then there exists a factorization $Y \rightarrow Y^{\prime} \rightarrow X$ of $i$ such that
(1) the morphism $Y \rightarrow Y^{\prime}$ is an isomorphism on underlying classical schemes,
(2) the morphism $Y^{\prime} \rightarrow X$ is a closed immersion locally of finite presentation and an isomorphism over $U$.

Proof. Let $\mathcal{I}=\operatorname{fib}\left(\mathcal{O}_{X} \rightarrow i_{*} \mathcal{O}_{Y}\right)$. As $i$ is a closed immersion and an isomorphism over $U$, we have $\mathcal{I} \in \operatorname{QCoh}(X$ on $Z)^{\mathrm{cn}}$. As the morphism of classical schemes ${ }^{\mathrm{cl}} Y \rightarrow{ }^{\mathrm{cl}} X$ is classically of finite presentation, it follows that the image $\mathcal{J}$ of $\pi_{0}(\mathcal{I})$ in $\pi_{0}\left(\mathcal{O}_{X}\right)$ is of finite type. By Lemma 2.1, we can write $\mathcal{I}$ as a filtered colimit $\mathcal{I}=\operatorname{colim}_{\alpha} \mathcal{I}_{\alpha}$ where each $I_{\alpha} \in \operatorname{Perf}(X$ on $Z)^{\mathrm{cn}}$. As $\pi_{0}(-)$ commutes with filtered colimits, we have $\operatorname{colim}_{\alpha} \pi_{0}\left(\mathcal{I}_{\alpha}\right)=\pi_{0}(\mathcal{I})$. As $\pi_{0}(\mathcal{I}) \rightarrow \mathcal{J}$ is surjective and $\mathcal{J}$ is of finite type, there exists an index $\alpha$ such that the induced map $\pi_{0}\left(\mathcal{I}_{\alpha}\right) \rightarrow \mathcal{J}$ is surjective. By construction, we have the following commutative diagram in $\operatorname{QCoh}(X)^{\mathrm{cn}}$.
![img-5.jpeg](img-5.jpeg)

By adjunction, this induces a commutative diagram
![img-6.jpeg](img-6.jpeg)
in $\operatorname{CAlg}_{\mathcal{O}_{X}}^{\Delta}$. We define $\mathcal{A} \in \operatorname{CAlg}_{\mathcal{O}_{X}}^{\Delta}$ to be the tensor product $\mathcal{O}_{X} \otimes_{\operatorname{LSym}_{\mathcal{O}_{X}}^{\Delta}\left(\mathcal{I}_{\alpha}\right)} \mathcal{O}_{X}$. The above diagram classifies a morphism $\mathcal{A} \rightarrow i_{*} \mathcal{O}_{Y}$ in $\operatorname{CAlg}_{\mathcal{O}_{X}}^{\Delta}$. We claim that it induces an

isomorphism on $\pi_{0}$. Indeed, we compute ${ }^{2}$

$$
\begin{aligned}
\pi_{0}(\mathcal{A}) & \cong \pi_{0}\left(\mathcal{O}_{X}\right) \otimes_{\pi_{0}\left(\operatorname{LSym}_{\mathcal{O}_{X}}^{\wedge}\left(\mathcal{I}_{\alpha}\right)\right)}^{\circ} \pi_{0}\left(\mathcal{O}_{X}\right) \\
& \cong \pi_{0}\left(\mathcal{O}_{X}\right) \otimes_{\operatorname{Sym}_{\pi_{0}\left(\mathcal{O}_{X}\right)}^{\circ}\left(\pi_{0}\left(\mathcal{I}_{\alpha}\right)\right)}^{\circ} \pi_{0}\left(\mathcal{O}_{X}\right) \\
& \cong \pi_{0}\left(\mathcal{O}_{X}\right) / \operatorname{im}\left(\pi_{0}\left(\mathcal{I}_{\alpha}\right) \rightarrow \pi_{0}\left(\mathcal{O}_{X}\right)\right) \\
& =\pi_{0}\left(\mathcal{O}_{X}\right) / \mathcal{J} \\
& \cong \pi_{0}\left(i_{*} \mathcal{O}_{Y}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

We set $Y^{\prime}=\operatorname{Spec}(\mathcal{A})$. By construction, we get the factorization $Y \rightarrow Y^{\prime} \rightarrow X$ of $i$. The above computation shows that $Y \rightarrow Y^{\prime}$ is an isomorphism on underlying classical schemes. Moreover, as $I_{\alpha}$ is supported on $Z, Y^{\prime} \rightarrow X$ is an isomorphism over $U$. Finally, as $I_{\alpha}$ is perfect, it follows that $Y^{\prime} \rightarrow X$ is locally of finite presentation, as desired.
2.5. Formal completion. Let $X$ be a qcqs derived scheme and let $Z \subseteq|X|$ be a closed subset whose open complement $|X| \backslash Z$ is quasi-compact. The formal completion $X_{Z}^{\wedge}$ is an ind-object of derived schemes with a map $i: X_{Z}^{\wedge} \rightarrow X$. It is determined by the following universal property: For any derived ring $R$, composition with $i$ induces an equivalence of $\operatorname{Map}_{\text {Ind(dish) }}\left(\operatorname{Spec}(R), X_{Z}^{\wedge}\right)$ with the union of components of $\operatorname{Map}_{\text {dish }}(\operatorname{Spec}(R), X)$ consisting of those morphisms $\operatorname{Spec}(R) \rightarrow X$ that set-theoretically factor through $Z$; see [GR14, Prop. 6.5.5] for the existence of $X_{Z}^{\wedge}$ as an ind-derived scheme. More concretely, we can write $X_{Z}^{\wedge}$ as the ind-system

$$
X_{Z}^{\wedge}=\left\{Z^{\prime}\right\}_{Z^{\prime} \hookrightarrow X}
$$

of (a small cofinal subsystem of) all closed immersions of derived schemes $Z^{\prime} \hookrightarrow X$ with $\left|Z^{\prime}\right|=Z$.

If $X=\operatorname{Spec}(A)$ is affine, there exist finitely many elements $f_{1}, \ldots, f_{r} \in \pi_{0}(A)$ whose zero locus is $Z$. In this case, $X_{Z}^{\wedge}$ can also be represented by

$$
X_{Z}^{\wedge}=\left\{\operatorname{Spec}\left(A_{\hat{\beta}} f_{1}^{\alpha}, \ldots, f_{r}^{\alpha}\right)\right\}_{\alpha \geq 1}
$$

where the symbol $\hat{\beta}$ indicates the derived quotient, i.e. the (derived) tensor product $A \otimes_{\mathbb{Z}\left[t_{1}, \ldots, t_{r}\right]}$ $\mathbb{Z}$ where the maps send $t_{i}$ to $f_{i}^{\alpha}$ and 0 , respectively; see [Lur04, Prop. 6.1.1] or [Lur18, Lemma 8.1.2.2].

It follows immediately from the universal property that the formation of the derived completion commutes with base change: If $f: Y \rightarrow X$ is a quasi-compact map, then $Y_{f^{-1}(Z)}^{\wedge} \simeq$ $X_{Z}^{\wedge} \times_{X} Y$. We therefore also write $Y_{Z}^{\wedge}$ instead of $Y_{f^{-1}(Z)}^{\wedge}$.

If $X$ is a Noetherian classical scheme, then the formal completion is itself classical, equal to the classical formal completion. This follows for example from [Lur18, Lemma 17.3.5.7].
2.6. Ample line bundles. Ample line bundles on Noetherian derived schemes have been studied by Annala [Ann22]. We need some of the results in the more general setting of qcqs derived schemes. These are certainly well-known, the proofs are essentially the same as for classical schemes.

Let $X$ be a qcqs derived scheme. A line bundle $\mathcal{L}$ on $X$ is called ample if for any point $x \in X$ there exists an $n \geq 1$ and a global section $s \in \pi_{0} \Gamma\left(X, \mathcal{L}^{\otimes n}\right)$ such that the non-vanishing locus $X_{s}$ of $s$ is affine and contains $x$. If $f: X \rightarrow Y$ is a morphism of derived schemes, then

[^0]
[^0]:    ${ }^{2}$ here the $\otimes^{\circ}$ indicates the underived tensor product and Sym denotes the classical symmetric algebra

$\mathcal{L}$ is called $f$-ample if for every affine open subscheme $U \subseteq Y$ the restriction of $\mathcal{L}$ to $f^{-1}(U)$ is ample.

Let now $\mathcal{L}$ be any line bundle on $X$ and $s \in \pi_{0} \Gamma(X, \mathcal{L})$ a global section. We view the latter as a map $s: \mathcal{O}_{X} \rightarrow \mathcal{L}$. If $\mathcal{F}$ is any quasi-coherent sheaf on $X$, we get a diagram

$$
\mathcal{F} \xrightarrow{\otimes s} \mathcal{F} \otimes \mathcal{L} \xrightarrow{\otimes s} \mathcal{F} \otimes \mathcal{L}^{\otimes 2} \longrightarrow \ldots
$$

In the case of classical schemes, the following lemma is standard. For Noetherian derived schemes, it is [Ann22, Lemma 2.6].

Lemma 2.3. In the above situation, there is a canonical equivalence

$$
\operatorname{colim}_{n} \Gamma\left(X, \mathcal{F} \otimes \mathcal{L}^{\otimes n}\right) \simeq \Gamma\left(X_{s}, \mathcal{F}\right)
$$

Proof. If we take sections over $X_{s}$ in (3), then all maps become equivalences. Thus the restriction maps induce a map

$$
\operatorname{colim}_{n} \Gamma\left(X, \mathcal{F} \otimes \mathcal{L}^{\otimes n}\right) \rightarrow \operatorname{colim}_{n} \Gamma\left(X_{s}, \mathcal{F} \otimes \mathcal{L}^{\otimes n}\right) \simeq \Gamma\left(X_{s}, \mathcal{F}\right)
$$

We claim that this map is an equivalence. As $X$ is qcqs, a standard induction reduces us to the case where $X=\operatorname{Spec}(A)$ is affine and $\mathcal{L}$ is trivial. So we may assume $X=\operatorname{Spec}(A)$, $\Gamma(X, \mathcal{L})=A$, and $\mathcal{F}$ corresponds to the $A$-module $M=\Gamma(X, \mathcal{F})$. In this case, the colimit in question identifies with $M\left[s^{-1}\right]$ which also identifies with $\Gamma\left(X_{s}, \mathcal{F}\right)$ as $\mathcal{F}$ is quasi-coherent.

Exactly as in [Ann22, Lemma 2.11], this can be used to prove the following lemma.
Lemma 2.4. Let $f: X \rightarrow Y$ be a morphism of qcqs derived schemes, $\mathcal{L}$ a line bundle on $X$, and $\left(U_{i}\right)_{i \in I}$ an open covering of $Y$. Write $f_{i}$ for the restricted morphism $f^{-1}\left(U_{i}\right) \rightarrow U_{i}$. Then the following are equivalent:
(1) $\mathcal{L}$ is $f$-ample;
(2) for every $i \in I$, the restriction $\left.\mathcal{L}\right|_{f^{-1}\left(U_{i}\right)}$ of $\mathcal{L}$ is $f_{i}$-ample.

The existence of an ample line bundle implies the resolution property in the following form:
Lemma 2.5. Let $X$ be a qcqs derived scheme which carries an ample line bundle, and let $\mathcal{F}$ be a connective, quasi-coherent $\mathcal{O}_{X}$-module such that $\pi_{0} \mathcal{F}$ is of finite type as a $\pi_{0} \mathcal{O}_{X}$-module. Then there exists a vector bundle, i.e. a locally free $\mathcal{O}_{X}$-module of finite rank, $\mathcal{E}$ on $X$ together with a map $\mathcal{E} \rightarrow \mathcal{F}$ which is surjective on $\pi_{0}$.

Proof. Choose an ample line bundle $\mathcal{L}$. Replacing $\mathcal{L}$ by an appropriate tensor power, we may assume that there exist finitely many global sections $s_{i} \in \pi_{0} \Gamma(X, \mathcal{L})$, whose non-vanishing loci $X_{s_{i}}$ form an affine covering of $X$. As each $X_{s_{i}}$ is affine and $\mathcal{F}$ is quasi-coherent, we have isomorphisms $\pi_{0} \Gamma\left(X_{s_{i}}, \mathcal{F}\right)=\pi_{0} \Gamma\left(X_{s_{i}}, \pi_{0} \mathcal{F}\right)$ and similarly for $\mathcal{O}_{X}$ in place of $\mathcal{F}$. The assumption that $\pi_{0} \mathcal{F}$ is a $\pi_{0} \mathcal{O}_{X}$-module of finite type then implies that each $\pi_{0} \Gamma\left(X_{s_{i}}, \mathcal{F}\right)$ is a finitely generated $\pi_{0} \Gamma\left(X_{s_{i}}, \mathcal{O}_{X}\right)$-module. Choose finitely many generators $m_{i j} \in \pi_{0} \Gamma\left(X_{s_{i}}, \mathcal{F}\right)$. By Lemma 2.3 there exists an integer $N$ such that all the $m_{i j}$ extend to global sections of $\mathcal{F} \otimes \mathcal{L}^{\otimes N}$. These give rise to a map $\mathcal{E}:=\bigoplus_{i j} \mathcal{L}^{\otimes(-N)} \rightarrow \mathcal{F}$ which is surjective on $\pi_{0}$ by construction.

2.7. Quasi-smooth closed immersions and derived blowups. Derived blowups were first introduced in [KST18] for affine schemes in order to prove pro-cdh descent of algebraic $K$-theory on Noetherian schemes. They were then systematically studied and developed much further by Khan, Rydh, and Hekking [KR18, Hek21].

Let $X$ be a derived scheme, and let $Z \hookrightarrow X$ be a quasi-smooth closed immersion [KR18, 2.3.6], i.e., Zariski locally on $X, Z \hookrightarrow X$ is the derived pullback of the map $\{0\} \hookrightarrow \mathbb{A}_{\underline{Z}}^{r}$ for some $r$ and some morphism $X \rightarrow \mathbb{A}_{\underline{Z}}^{r}$. Equivalently, Zariski locally on $X, Z \hookrightarrow X$ is given by $\operatorname{Spec}\left(A \nless f_{1}, \ldots, f_{r}\right) \hookrightarrow \operatorname{Spec}(A)$ for suitable elements $f_{i} \in \pi_{0}(A)$. The number $r$ is called the virtual codimension of the closed immersion. Then one can form the derived blowup $p: \mathrm{dBl}_{Z}(X) \rightarrow X$ of $X$ in $Z$ (or with center $Z$ ) which is characterized by a universal property: it classifies virtual Cartier divisors on derived $X$-schemes; see [KR18, §4.1] for details. The construction of the derived blowup commutes with arbitrary base change. Locally, if $Z$ is the derived pullback of $\{0\} \hookrightarrow \mathbb{A}_{\underline{Z}}^{r}$ along a map $X \rightarrow \mathbb{A}_{\underline{Z}}^{r}$, then $\mathrm{dBl}_{Z}(X)$ is the derived pullback of the classical blowup $\mathrm{Bl}_{\{0\}}\left(\mathbb{A}_{\underline{Z}}^{r}\right) \rightarrow \mathbb{A}_{\underline{Z}}^{r}$. By [KR18, Thm. 4.1.5(v)], the morphism $p: \mathrm{dBl}_{Z}(X) \rightarrow X$ is quasi-smooth, i.e. Zariski locally factors as a quasi-smooth closed immersion followed by a smooth morphism, and in particular is locally of finite presentation. Clearly, $p$ is an isomorphism outside $Z$ and proper.

It follows from the description of the underlying classical scheme of $\mathrm{dBl}_{Z}(X)$ in [KR18, Thm. 4.1.5(vii)] that there is always a closed immersion $\mathrm{Bl}_{\mathrm{cl}_{Z}}\left({ }^{\mathrm{cl}} X\right) \hookrightarrow{ }^{\mathrm{cl}} \mathrm{dBl}_{Z}(X)$ and this is an isomorphism over ${ }^{\mathrm{cl}} U$ where $U$ is the open complement of $Z$.

The derived blowup $\mathrm{dBl}_{Z}(X)$ carries a canonical line bundle $\mathcal{O}(1)$ (the ideal sheaf defining the universal virtual Cartier divisor) and this line bundle is $p$-ample. Indeed, by Lemma 2.4 we may work affine-locally on $X$ and hence assume that $p: \mathrm{dBl}_{Z}(X) \rightarrow X$ is the pullback of the classical blowup $\mathrm{Bl}_{\{0\}}\left(\mathbb{A}_{\underline{Z}}^{n}\right) \rightarrow \mathbb{A}_{\underline{Z}}^{n}$, and the line bundle $\mathcal{O}(1)$ is the pullback of the classical canonical line bundle on $\mathrm{Bl}_{\{0\}}\left(\mathbb{A}^{n}\right)$ which is ample. As being relatively ample is stable under base change (the proof in [Ann22, Prop. 2.12] works in general), it follows that $\mathcal{O}(1)$ is $p$-ample.

In presence of an ample line bundle, every closed subset with quasi-compact complement is the support of a quasi-smooth closed subscheme. More precisely, we have the following lemma.

Lemma 2.6. Let $X$ be a qcqs derived scheme which carries an ample line bundle. Let $Z_{0} \hookrightarrow$ ${ }^{\mathrm{cl}} X$ be a classically finitely presented closed subscheme. Then there exists a quasi-smooth closed subscheme $Z \hookrightarrow X$ whose classical truncation is $Z_{0}$.

Proof. This is very similar to [BKRS22, Constr. A.2.2]. Let $J=\operatorname{fib}\left(\mathcal{O}_{X} \rightarrow \mathcal{O}_{Z_{0}}\right)$. As $\mathcal{O}_{Z_{0}}$ is a discrete, quasi-coherent sheaf and $\mathcal{O}_{X} \rightarrow \mathcal{O}_{Z_{0}}$ is surjective on $\pi_{0}$, the sheaf $J$ is connective, quasi-coherent, and $\pi_{0} J$ is the ideal sheaf defining $Z_{0}$ in ${ }^{\mathrm{cl}} X$. As $Z_{0} \hookrightarrow{ }^{\mathrm{cl}} X$ is classically of finite presentation, $\pi_{0} J$ is a $\pi_{0} \mathcal{O}_{X}$-module of finite type. Hence Lemma 2.5 implies the existence of a vector bundle $\mathcal{E}$ on $X$ and a map $\mathcal{E} \rightarrow \mathcal{J}$ which is surjective on $\pi_{0}$. Let $V(\mathcal{E})$ be the geometric vector bundle $V(\mathcal{E}):=\operatorname{Spec}\left(\operatorname{LSym}_{\mathcal{O}_{X}}^{s}(\mathcal{E})\right)$ over $X$. The composition $\mathcal{E} \rightarrow \mathcal{J} \rightarrow \mathcal{O}_{X}$ defines a section $s: X \rightarrow V(\mathcal{E})$, and we form the fibre product
![img-7.jpeg](img-7.jpeg)

Equivalently, we have

$$
Z=\operatorname{Spec}\left(\mathcal{O}_{X} \otimes_{\mathrm{LSym}_{\mathfrak{F}_{X}}(\mathcal{E})} \mathcal{O}_{X}\right)
$$

By construction, $i: Z \hookrightarrow X$ is quasi-smooth. The same computation as in the proof of Lemma 2.2 shows that ${ }^{i \prime} Z=Z_{0}$, as desired.
2.8. Pushouts of derived schemes. We also need certain pushouts of derived schemes. These have been studied in [GR17]:

Lemma 2.7. Let $i: Y_{1} \rightarrow Y_{1}^{\prime}$ be a closed immersion of derived schemes which is an isomorphism on underlying topological spaces, and let $f: Y_{1} \rightarrow Y_{2}$ be an affine map in dSch. Then the following hold.
(1) The pushout square
![img-8.jpeg](img-8.jpeg)
exists in dSch. Write $Y_{2}^{\prime}:=Y_{2} \sqcup_{Y_{1}} Y_{1}^{\prime}$. The map $Y_{2} \rightarrow Y_{2}^{\prime}$ is a closed immersion and an isomorphism on underlying topological spaces. In particular, if $Y_{2}$ is qcqs, then so is $Y_{2}^{\prime}$.
(2) For an affine open subscheme $U_{2} \subseteq Y_{2}$ with $U_{1}:=f^{-1}\left(U_{2}\right) \subseteq Y_{1}$, and the corresponding open subschemes $U_{i}^{\prime} \subseteq Y_{i}^{\prime}(i=1,2)$, the map

$$
U_{2} \sqcup_{U_{1}} U_{1}^{\prime} \rightarrow U_{2}^{\prime}
$$

is an isomorphism.
(3) If $f$ is an open immersion, then so is $f^{\prime}$.
(4) Assume $i$ exhibits $Y_{1}$ as the underlying classical scheme of $Y_{1}^{\prime}$. Then $i^{\prime}: Y_{2} \rightarrow Y_{2}^{\prime}$ is an isomorphism on underlying classical schemes.

Proof. Except for (4), this is [GR17, Ch. 1, Cor. 1.3.5]. By (2), we may assume $Y_{i}=\operatorname{Spec}\left(A_{i}\right)$ $(i=1,2)$ and $Y_{1}^{\prime}=\operatorname{Spec}\left(A_{1}^{\prime}\right)$ are affine and $A_{1}=\pi_{0}\left(A_{1}^{\prime}\right)$. By the construction of the pushout, $Y_{2}^{\prime}=\operatorname{Spec}\left(A_{2}^{\prime}\right)$ where $A_{2}^{\prime}=A_{2} \times_{A_{1}} A_{1}^{\prime}$ is the pullback in derived rings. We thus have an exact sequence of homotopy groups

$$
\pi_{1}\left(A_{1}\right) \rightarrow \pi_{0}\left(A_{2}^{\prime}\right) \rightarrow \pi_{0}\left(A_{2}\right) \oplus \pi_{0}\left(A_{1}^{\prime}\right) \rightarrow \pi_{0}\left(A_{1}\right)
$$

which implies (4) as $\pi_{1}\left(A_{1}\right)=0$ and $\pi_{0}\left(A_{1}^{\prime}\right) \cong \pi_{0}\left(A_{1}\right)$.

# 3. Modifications of Derived SCHEMES 

In the following, $X$ always denotes a qcqs derived scheme.
Definition 3.1. Let $U \subseteq X$ be a quasi-compact open subscheme. A $U$-modification of $X$ is a proper morphism $f: Y \rightarrow X$ which is an isomorphism over $U$. A closed $U$-modification is a $U$-modification which is a closed immersion.

Note that we do not assume that a $U$-modification induces a bijection of the set of generic points. For example, if $Z \hookrightarrow X$ is a quasi-smooth closed immersion with $|Z| \cap|U|=\emptyset$, then the derived blowup $\mathrm{Bl}_{Z}(X) \rightarrow X$ is a $U$-modification which is moreover lafp (see 2.7). In fact, derived blowups and lafp closed $U$-modifications generate all lafp $U$-modifications in the following sense:

Theorem 3.2. Assume that $X$ carries an ample line bundle. Let $U \subseteq X$ be a quasi-compact open subscheme. Let $f: Y \rightarrow X$ be a $U$-modification of $X$, whose underlying map of classical schemes ${ }^{\mathrm{cl}} Y \rightarrow{ }^{\mathrm{cl}} X$ is classically finitely presented. Then there exists a commutative diagram
![img-9.jpeg](img-9.jpeg)
where $g$ is $U$-modification of $Y, h$ is a closed $U$-modification, $p$ is a derived blowup with center set-theoretically contained in $X \backslash U$, and the induced map $(h, g): Y^{\prime} \rightarrow \widetilde{X} \times_{X} Y$ is locally of finite presentation. In particular, $g$ is locally of finite presentation, and, if $f$ is locally of finite presentation (or lafp, or locally of finite generation to order $n$, respectively), then $h$ is locally of finite presentation (or lafp, or locally of finite generation to order $n$ ).

Moreover, $Y^{\prime}$ carries a $(p \circ h)$-ample line bundle.
Proof. By assumption, the morphism of classical schemes ${ }^{\mathrm{cl}} f:{ }^{\mathrm{cl}} Y \rightarrow{ }^{\mathrm{cl}} X$ is proper and classically of finite presentation. It is also an isomorphism over ${ }^{\mathrm{cl}} U$. By [RG71, Cor. 5.7.12] (or [Sta25, Tag 081T]), there exists a ${ }^{\mathrm{cl}} U$-admissible blowup ${ }^{3} Y_{0} \rightarrow{ }^{\mathrm{cl}} X$ such that the morphism $Y_{0} \rightarrow{ }^{\mathrm{cl}} X$ factors through ${ }^{\mathrm{cl}} Y \rightarrow{ }^{\mathrm{cl}} X$. For the constructions to come, we need the open immersion ${ }^{\mathrm{cl}} U \rightarrow Y_{0}$ to be affine. As this is not necessarily the case, we make a further blowup: As ${ }^{\mathrm{cl}} U$ is quasi-compact, there exists a finitely presented closed subscheme $T_{0} \hookrightarrow Y_{0}$ whose underlying topological space is $Y_{0} \backslash{ }^{\mathrm{cl}} U$ : This follows for instance from [GD71, Cor. 6.9.15] which allows us to write the ideal sheaf of some closed subscheme of $Y_{0}$ with support $Y_{0} \backslash{ }^{\mathrm{cl}} U$ as a filtered colimit of quasi-coherent sub-ideal sheaves of finite type. By quasi-compactness of ${ }^{\mathrm{cl}} U$, the closed subscheme defined by one of them will have support $Y_{0} \backslash{ }^{\mathrm{cl}} U$. Let $Y_{1} \rightarrow Y_{0}$ be the blowup of $Y_{0}$ in $T_{0}$. Then the canonical open immersion ${ }^{\mathrm{cl}} U \rightarrow Y_{1}$ is affine as its complement is a Cartier divisor. As the composite of two ${ }^{\mathrm{cl}} U$-admissible blowups is a ${ }^{\mathrm{cl}} U$ admissible blowup [Sta25, Tag 080L], the composition $Y_{1} \rightarrow Y_{0} \rightarrow{ }^{\mathrm{cl}} X$ is a ${ }^{\mathrm{cl}} U$-admissible blowup, say $Y_{1}=\mathrm{Bl}_{S_{0}}\left({ }^{\mathrm{cl}} X\right)$ for some classically finitely presented closed subscheme $S_{0} \hookrightarrow{ }^{\mathrm{cl}} X$.

As $X$ carries an ample line bundle, Lemma 2.6 implies the existence of a quasi-smooth closed immersion of derived schemes $S \hookrightarrow X$ whose classical truncation is $S_{0} \hookrightarrow{ }^{\mathrm{cl}} X$. Let $p: \widetilde{X} \rightarrow X$ be the derived blowup of $X$ in $S$. Then there is a canonical closed immersion $Y_{1} \hookrightarrow{ }^{\mathrm{cl}} \widetilde{X}$, which is an isomorphism over ${ }^{\mathrm{cl}} U$. Note that $Y_{1}$ need not be classically of finite presentation over $X$. However, using [GD71, Cor. 6.9.15] again we see that the closed immersion $Y_{1} \hookrightarrow{ }^{\mathrm{cl}} \widetilde{X}$ can be written as a cofiltered limit of classically finitely presented closed immersions $Y_{\alpha} \rightarrow{ }^{\mathrm{cl}} \widetilde{X}$ all of which are isomorphisms over ${ }^{\mathrm{cl}} U$. As ${ }^{\mathrm{cl}} Y \rightarrow{ }^{\mathrm{cl}} X$ is classically of finite presentation, there exists an $\alpha$ such that the ${ }^{\mathrm{cl}} X$-morphism $Y_{1} \rightarrow{ }^{\mathrm{cl}} Y$ factors through a morphism $Y_{\alpha} \rightarrow{ }^{\mathrm{cl}} Y$, see [Gro66, Prop. 8.14.2]. Thus, so far, we have constructed a commutative diagram of classical

schemes finitely presented over ${ }^{\mathrm{cl}} X$
![img-10.jpeg](img-10.jpeg)
in which all morphisms are isomorphisms over ${ }^{\mathrm{cl}} U$. The lower right corner is the classical truncation of the cospan $\widetilde{X} \stackrel{p}{\rightleftarrows} X \stackrel{f}{\rightleftarrows} Y$.

As the composite of the affine open immersion ${ }^{\mathrm{cl}} U \rightarrow Y_{1}$ with the closed immersion $Y_{1} \hookrightarrow$ $Y_{\alpha}$, the open immersion ${ }^{\mathrm{cl}} U \rightarrow Y_{\alpha}$ is affine, too. By Lemma 2.7 we may hence form the pushout $Y_{2}=Y_{\alpha} \sqcup_{\cup} U$ of derived schemes, for which we have ${ }^{\mathrm{cl}} Y_{2}=Y_{\alpha}$. As $p$ and $f$ are isomorphisms over $U$, we get induced morphisms $h_{2}: Y_{2} \rightarrow \widetilde{X}, g_{2}: Y_{2} \rightarrow Y$, and a commutative diagram
![img-11.jpeg](img-11.jpeg)

Note that $h_{2}$ is a closed immersion, as this only depends on the underlying map of classical schemes. Moreover, all morphisms in the above diagram are $U$-modifications. However, $h_{2}$ and $g_{2}$ need not satisfy the desired finiteness condition. In order to remedy this, we consider the induced morphism $k_{2}=\left(h_{2}, g_{2}\right): Y_{2} \rightarrow \widetilde{X} \times_{X} Y$. As ${ }^{\mathrm{cl}} Y \rightarrow{ }^{\mathrm{cl}} X$ is separated, and as $h_{2}$ is a closed immersion, $k_{2}$ is a closed immersion, too. It is also an isomorphism over $U$. By construction, the map of underlying classical schemes ${ }^{\mathrm{cl}} k_{2}: Y_{\alpha}={ }^{\mathrm{cl}} Y_{2} \rightarrow{ }^{\mathrm{cl}}\left(\widetilde{X} \times_{X} Y\right)$ is classically of finite presentation. We can hence apply Lemma 2.2 to obtain a factorization of $k_{2}$ through a closed derived subscheme $k^{\prime}: Y^{\prime} \hookrightarrow \widetilde{X} \times_{X} Y$ such that $k^{\prime}$ is locally of finite presentation and an isomorphism over $U$, and ${ }^{\mathrm{cl}} Y^{\prime} \cong{ }^{\mathrm{cl}} Y_{2}$. Define $g$ and $h$ to be the composites of $k^{\prime}$ with the two projections from $\widetilde{X} \times_{X} Y$ to $Y$ and $\widetilde{X}$, respectively. Both are $U$-modifications. As $p: \widetilde{X} \rightarrow X$ is locally of finite presentation, so is the first projection, and hence $g$. If $f$ is locally of finite presentation (or lafp, or locally of finite generation to order $n$ ), then so is the second projection and hence also $h$. As the underlying map of classical schemes ${ }^{\mathrm{cl}} h$ identifies with ${ }^{\mathrm{cl}} h_{2}:{ }^{\mathrm{cl}} Y_{2} \hookrightarrow{ }^{\mathrm{cl}} \widetilde{X}$, it is a closed immersion. This finishes the construction of the asserted commutative diagram, and the proof of the required finiteness conditions.

It remains to prove the claim about ample line bundles. As discussed in 2.7, the canonical line bundle $\mathcal{O}(1)$ on the derived blowup $\widetilde{X}$ is $p$-ample. As $h$ is a closed immersion and thus in particular affine, the pullback $h^{*} \mathcal{O}(1)$ is then $(p \circ h)$-ample.

# 4. Pro-CDH DESCENT FOR CONNECTIVE LOCALIZING INVARIANTS 

In this section, we prove our main results on pro-descent for localizing invariants. The strategy is the same as in [KST18]: We first prove the result for the special cases of derived blowups and finite modifications and then use the geometric input from Theorem 3.2 to handle the general case.

We begin by fixing some notation. Let $k$ be a fixed commutative base ring (e.g. $k=\mathbb{Z}$ ). If $E$ is an additive invariant of small $k$-linear $\infty$-categories with values in a stable presentable $\infty$-category $\mathcal{C}$, e.g. the $\infty$-category of spectra, and $X$ is a qcqs derived $k$-scheme, we write

$E(X)$ for $E(\operatorname{Perf}(X))$. Let $Z \subseteq|X|$ be a closed subset with quasi-compact open complement. Recall from 2.5 that the formal completion $X_{Z}^{\wedge}$ is an ind-derived scheme. Applying $E$ we thus obtain a pro-object $E\left(X_{Z}^{\wedge}\right)$. We write $E\left(X, X_{Z}^{\wedge}\right)$ for the relative term $\operatorname{fib}\left(E(X) \rightarrow E\left(X_{Z}^{\wedge}\right)\right)$ in $\operatorname{Pro}(\mathcal{C})$.

A version of the following Proposition was first proven in [KST18]. There all schemes were assumed to be classical Noetherian schemes, $E$ was $K$-theory, and the result only gave a weakly cartesian square of pro-spectra, see below for this notion. In a letter to Kerz, Antieau [Ant18] described a simplification of the proof which at the same time gives a cartesian square. We thank Ben Antieau for allowing us to include his argument in our paper.

Proposition 4.1. Let $X, Z$, and $E$ be as above. Let $\widetilde{X} \rightarrow X$ be a derived blowup in some quasi-smooth closed immersion $S \hookrightarrow X$ with $S$ set-theoretically contained in $Z$. Then the square
![img-12.jpeg](img-12.jpeg)
is cartesian in $\operatorname{Pro}(\mathcal{C})$.
Proof. Let $r \geq 1$ be the virtual codimension of the derived blowup, and let $D$ be its exceptional divisor, i.e., the universal virtual Cartier divisor on the derived blowup, so that there is a commutative diagram
![img-13.jpeg](img-13.jpeg)

Recall from [Kha20, Thm. C] that $\operatorname{Perf}(\widetilde{X})$ has a semi-orthogonal decomposition as follows. The functor $p^{*}: \operatorname{Perf}(X) \rightarrow \operatorname{Perf}(\widetilde{X})$ is fully faithful, denote its essential image by $\mathcal{B}(0)$. For $1 \leq k \leq r-1$, the composed functor $j_{*}\left(q^{*}(-) \otimes_{\mathcal{O}_{D}} \mathcal{O}_{D}(-k)\right): \operatorname{Perf}(S) \rightarrow \operatorname{Perf}(\widetilde{X})$ is fully faithful, denote its essential image by $\mathcal{B}(-k)$. Then the sequence of full subcategories $(\mathcal{B}(0), \mathcal{B}(-1), \ldots, \mathcal{B}(-r+1))$ forms a semi-orthogonal decomposition of $\operatorname{Perf}(\widetilde{X})$. In particular, there is a decomposition

$$
E(\widetilde{X}) \simeq E(\mathcal{B}(0)) \oplus \bigoplus_{k=1}^{r-1} E(\mathcal{B}(-k)) \simeq E(X) \oplus \bigoplus_{k=1}^{r-1} E(S)
$$

Now let $Z^{\prime} \hookrightarrow X$ be any closed derived subscheme with $\left|Z^{\prime}\right|=Z$. Note that all $\infty$-categories appearing above are in fact $\operatorname{Perf}(X)$-linear, as are the functors between them. In particular, we can base change the semi-orthogonal decomposition of $\operatorname{Perf}(\widetilde{X})$ along $\operatorname{Perf}(X) \rightarrow \operatorname{Perf}\left(Z^{\prime}\right)$. As there are canonical equivalences (as follows from [Lur18, Cor. 9.4.3.8] by passing to compact objects; see also [BZFN10, Thm. 4.7] with slightly different hypotheses)

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \operatorname{Perf}(\widetilde{X}) \otimes_{\operatorname{Perf}(X)} \operatorname{Perf}\left(Z^{\prime}\right) \simeq \operatorname{Perf}\left(\widetilde{X} \times_{X} Z^{\prime}\right) \\
& \operatorname{Perf}(S) \otimes_{\operatorname{Perf}(X)} \operatorname{Perf}\left(Z^{\prime}\right) \simeq \operatorname{Perf}\left(S \times_{X} Z^{\prime}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

we conclude that $\operatorname{Perf}\left(\widetilde{X} \times_{X} Z^{\prime}\right)$ admits a semi-orthogonal decomposition

$$
\left(\mathcal{B}(0)_{Z^{\prime}}, \mathcal{B}(-1)_{Z^{\prime}}, \ldots, \mathcal{B}(-r+1)_{Z^{\prime}}\right)
$$

with $\mathcal{B}(0)_{Z^{\prime}} \simeq \operatorname{Perf}\left(Z^{\prime}\right)$ and $\mathcal{B}(-k)_{Z^{\prime}} \simeq \operatorname{Perf}\left(S \times_{X} Z^{\prime}\right)$ for $1 \leq k \leq r-1$. In particular,

$$
E\left(\widetilde{X} \times_{X} Z^{\prime}\right) \simeq E\left(Z^{\prime}\right) \oplus \bigoplus_{k=1}^{r-1} E\left(S \times_{X} Z^{\prime}\right)
$$

Recall from (1) that $E\left(X_{Z}^{\wedge}\right) \in \operatorname{Pro}(\mathcal{C})$ is given concretely as the pro-object $\left\{E\left(Z^{\prime}\right)\right\}_{Z^{\prime} \hookrightarrow X,\left|Z^{\prime}\right|=Z}$ where $Z^{\prime}$ runs through all closed derived subschemes of $X$ with $\left|Z^{\prime}\right|=Z$. As formal completion is compatible with base change (see 2.5), we similarly have $E\left(\widetilde{X}_{Z}^{\wedge}\right)=\left\{E\left(\widetilde{X} \times_{X}\right.\right.$ $\left.\left.Z^{\prime}\right)\right\}_{Z^{\prime} \hookrightarrow X,\left|Z^{\prime}\right|=Z}$. Comparing the decompositions (4) and (5) it thus suffices to prove that the functor induced by pullback

$$
\operatorname{Perf}(S) \rightarrow\left\{\operatorname{Perf}\left(S \times_{X} Z^{\prime}\right)\right\}_{Z^{\prime} \hookrightarrow X,\left|Z^{\prime}\right|=Z}
$$

is an equivalence of pro- $\infty$-categories. For this, it suffices to check that the map of ind-derived schemes $\left\{S \times_{X} Z^{\prime}\right\}_{Z^{\prime} \hookrightarrow X,\left|Z^{\prime}\right|=Z} \rightarrow S$ is an equivalence. But this is clear: By 2.5 again, the source represents the $Z$-completion $S_{Z}^{\wedge}$ of the target. As $S$ is set-theoretically contained in $Z$, we clearly have $S_{Z}^{\wedge}=S$.

Let $\ell$ be an integer. Recall from [LT19, Def. 2.5] that a spectra valued localizing invariant $E$ is called $\ell$-connective if, for any $n$-connective map $(n \geq 1)$ of connective $\mathbb{E}_{1}$-ring spectra $A \rightarrow B$, the induced map $E(A) \rightarrow E(B)$ is $(n+\ell)$-connective. For example, $K$-theory, topological cyclic homology TC and rational negative cyclic homology $\mathrm{HN}(-\otimes \mathbb{Q} / \mathbb{Q})$ are 1-connective, THH is 0 -connective; see [LT19, Ex. 2.6].

Recall also that a map of pro-spectra $\left\{C_{\alpha}\right\}_{\alpha} \rightarrow\left\{D_{\alpha}\right\}_{\alpha}$ is called a weak equivalence if each truncation $\left\{\tau_{\leq n} C_{\alpha}\right\}_{\alpha} \rightarrow\left\{\tau_{\leq n} D_{\alpha}\right\}_{\alpha}$ is an equivalence in $\operatorname{Pro}(\mathrm{Sp})$ and there are similar notions of being weakly cartesian, weakly contractible, and so on; see [LT19, Def. 2.27].

Proposition 4.2. Let $E$ be a localizing invariant of small $k$-linear $\infty$-categories that is $\ell$ connective for some integer $\ell$. Let $f: Y \rightarrow X$ be a finite, lafp morphism of qcqs derived $k$-schemes which is an isomorphism outside the closed subset $Z$ with $|X| \backslash Z$ quasi-compact. Then the commutative square of pro-spectra
![img-14.jpeg](img-14.jpeg)
is weakly cartesian.
Proof. We first reduce to the case that $X$ is affine: As $X$ is qcqs, we can write $X$ as the colimit of a finite diagram of open affine subschemes $V_{i} \hookrightarrow X$. As any localizing invariant satisfies Zariski descent, we get $E(X)=\lim _{i} E\left(V_{i}\right)$ and $E(Y)=\lim _{i} E\left(Y \times_{X} V_{i}\right)$. If $Z^{\prime} \hookrightarrow X$ is a closed subscheme with $\left|Z^{\prime}\right|=Z$, we also have $E\left(Z^{\prime}\right)=\lim _{i} E\left(V_{i} \times_{X} Z^{\prime}\right)$. As finite limits in $\operatorname{Pro}(\mathcal{C})$ are computed level-wise and formal completion is compatible with base change, this implies $E\left(X_{Z}^{\wedge}\right)=\lim _{i} E\left(\left(V_{i}\right)_{Z}^{\wedge}\right)$ and similarly for $E\left(Y_{Z}^{\wedge}\right)$. Replacing $X$ by $V_{i}$ and $Z$ by $V_{i} \cap Z$ we thus reduce to the case that $X$ is affine.

So assume now that $X$ is affine, say $X=\operatorname{Spec}(A)$. As $f$ is finite, also $Y$ is affine, say $Y=\operatorname{Spec}(B)$. Let $\phi: A \rightarrow B$ be the corresponding morphism of derived rings and write $J=\operatorname{fib}(A \rightarrow B)$. As $A$ and $B$ are connective, $J$ is $(-1)$-connective. By [Lur18, Cor. 5.2.2.2]

the $A$-algebra $B$ is almost perfect as an $A$-module, hence also $J$ is almost perfect as an $A$-module, i.e. $\tau_{\leq n} J$ is a compact object in $\tau_{\leq n+1} \operatorname{Mod}(A)_{\geq-1}=\operatorname{Mod}(A)_{[-1, n]}$ for every $n .^{4}$

Choose $f_{1}, \ldots, f_{r} \in \pi_{0}(A)$ whose zero set is $Z$. Recall from (2) that $X_{Z}^{\simeq}$ is then represented by the ind-derived scheme $\left\{\operatorname{Spec}\left(A \nless f_{1}^{\alpha}, \ldots, f_{r}^{\alpha}\right)\right\}_{\alpha \geq 1}$. Consider the commutative diagram of derived rings
![img-15.jpeg](img-15.jpeg)

We claim that as pro-system in $\alpha$, this square is weakly cartesian. The map of vertical fibres (in $A$-modules) is the canonical map

$$
J \longrightarrow J \nless f_{1}^{\alpha}, \ldots, f_{r}^{\alpha}
$$

so we have to prove that this map is a weak equivalence as a pro-system in $\alpha$. For any $i=1, \ldots, r$, the fibre of the map of pro-systems $J \rightarrow\left\{J \nless f_{i}^{\alpha}\right\}_{\alpha}$ is the pro-system

$$
\left\{J \stackrel{f_{i}}{\longleftarrow} J \stackrel{f_{i}}{\longleftarrow} \ldots\right\}
$$

We show below that this system is weakly contractible. We then get weak equivalences $J \xrightarrow{\simeq}\left\{J \nless f_{1}^{\alpha}\right\}_{\alpha}$ and, taking derived quotients by powers of $f_{2},\left\{J \nless f_{2}^{\alpha}\right\}_{\alpha} \xrightarrow{\simeq}\left\{J \nless f_{1}^{\alpha}, f_{2}^{\alpha}\right\}_{\alpha}$. Composing with $J \xrightarrow{\simeq}\left\{J \nless f_{2}^{\alpha}\right\}_{\alpha}$ we get the weak equivalence $J \xrightarrow{\simeq}\left\{J \nless f_{1}^{\alpha}, f_{2}^{\alpha}\right\}_{\alpha}$ and continuing like this we finally arrive at the weak equivalence $J \xrightarrow{\simeq}\left\{J \nless f_{1}^{\alpha}, \ldots, f_{r}^{\alpha}\right\}_{\alpha}$. So $\{(7)\}_{\alpha}$ is indeed weakly cartesian.

The assumption that $f$ be an isomorphism outside $Z$ implies that $J\left[f_{i}^{-1}\right]=0$ for $i=$ $1, \ldots, r$. Note that

$$
J\left[f_{i}^{-1}\right]=\operatorname{colim}\left(J \xrightarrow{f_{i}} J \xrightarrow{f_{i}} J \xrightarrow{f_{i}} \ldots\right)
$$

As the standard t-structure on $\operatorname{Mod}(A)$ is compatible with filtered colimits, we have

$$
0=\tau_{\leq n} J\left[f_{i}^{-1}\right]=\operatorname{colim}\left(\tau_{\leq n} J \xrightarrow{f_{i}} \tau_{\leq n} J \xrightarrow{f_{i}} \tau_{\leq n} J \xrightarrow{f_{i}} \ldots\right)
$$

As $\tau_{\leq n} J$ is compact in $\operatorname{Mod}(A)_{[-1, n]}$, we have

$$
0=\pi_{0}\left(\operatorname{map}\left(\tau_{\leq n} J, \tau_{\leq n} J\left[f_{i}^{-1}\right]\right)\right) \cong \operatorname{colim} \pi_{0}\left(\operatorname{map}\left(\tau_{\leq n} J, \tau_{\leq n} J\right)\right)
$$

which means that there is an $N$ such that the power $f_{i}^{N}$ acts nullhomotopically on $\tau_{\leq n} J$. It follows that (8) is weakly contractible, and hence the pro-system of squares $\{(7)\}_{\alpha}$ is indeed weakly cartesian.

Note that for every $\alpha$ the canonical map $B \otimes_{A}\left(A \nless f_{1}^{\alpha}, \ldots, f_{r}^{\alpha}\right) \rightarrow B \nless f_{1}^{\alpha}, \ldots, f_{r}^{\alpha}$ is an equivalence. Thus we may apply the variant of [LT19, Thm. 2.32] for $\ell$-connective localizing invariants to deduce that $\{(7)\}_{\alpha}$ induces a weakly cartesian square of $E$-theory pro-spectra.

Remark 4.3. In Proposition 4.2 one can actually relax the finiteness assumption if one adds other hypotheses: As the proof shows, we only need that the pro-systems (8) are weakly

If $X$ and $Y$ are $n$-truncated, then also $J$ is $n$-truncated. It is then enough to assume that $J$ is perfect to order $n$ in the sense of [Lur18, Def. 2.7.0.1] in order to conclude that the pro-systems (8) are weakly contractible.

As a special case, if the map $f$ in Proposition 4.2 is a closed immersion of classical qcqs schemes which is classically finitely presented, then the conclusion of the proposition holds, i.e. (6) is weakly cartesian. On the other hand, we cannot drop the finite presentation assumption, as the following example shows.

Example 4.4. Let $A$ be a discrete, commutative ring containing an element $f$ and a nontrivial ideal $J$ such that $J\left[f^{-1}\right]=0$ and $J$ is $f$-divisible. Note that this implies that $J^{2}=0$. For example, take $A=\mathbb{Z} \oplus \mathbb{Q}_{p} / \mathbb{Z}_{p}, f=p, J=\mathbb{Q}_{p} / \mathbb{Z}_{p}$.

The closed immersion $Y=\operatorname{Spec}(A / J) \rightarrow X=\operatorname{Spec}(A)$ is then an isomorphism outside $Z=V(f)$. We claim that the square
![img-16.jpeg](img-16.jpeg)
is not weakly cartesian.
Aiming at a contradiction, assume (9) is weakly cartesian. Fix some positive integer $n$. As $J$ is $f$-divisible,

$$
J \nless f^{n}=\operatorname{fib}\left(A \nless f^{n} \rightarrow(A / J) \nless f^{n}\right)
$$

is 1-connective. As a consequence, the map of $K$-theory spectra

$$
K\left(A \nless f^{n}\right) \rightarrow K\left((A / J) \nless f^{n}\right)
$$

is 2 -connective. So also the right vertical map, and hence the left vertical map in (9) is 2 -connective. In particular, the map $K_{1}(A) \rightarrow K_{1}(A / J)$ is an isomorphism. However, its retract $A^{*} \rightarrow(A / J)^{*}$ is not injective as every $1+x$ with $x \in J$ is an element of its kernel.

Remark 4.5. There is a version of the above Proposition for stacks: Let $X$ be a qcqs ANS derived algebraic stack [BKRS22, A.1], $Y \rightarrow X$ a finite, locally almost finitely presented morphism of derived algebraic stacks, and $Z \hookrightarrow X$ a closed immersion with quasi-compact open complement. Let $E$ be any connected localizing invariant in the sense of [BKRS22, Def. C.1.3] (e.g. a 2-connective or a finitary 1-connective localizing [BKRS22, Rem. C.1.5]). Then the square (6) of pro-spectra is weakly cartesian.

Indeed, the proof of [BKRS22, Thm. 4.2.1] works with the following changes: As in the proof of Lemma 2.3.2 in op. cit., the proof of our Proposition 4.2 shows that the formally completed square

is weakly cocartesian. As in the proof of Theorem 2.4.1 of op. cit. this implies that the square of derived (pro-)categories induced by (10) is weak pro-Milnor and satisfies weak pro-base

We now come to our main descent result, which in particular includes Theorem A.
Theorem 4.6. Let $E$ be a localizing invariant of small $k$-linear $\infty$-categories which is $\ell$ connective for some integer $\ell$. Let $X$ be a qcqs derived $k$-scheme, $U \subseteq X$ a quasi-compact open subscheme, and denote by $Z$ the closed subset $X \backslash U$. Let $f: Y \rightarrow X$ be a locally almost finitely presented $U$-modification of $X$. Then the square of pro-spectra
![img-18.jpeg](img-18.jpeg)
is weakly cartesian.
If $X$ and $Y$ are Noetherian classical schemes, and $f$ is classically of finite type, then $f$ is lafp (see 2.4). Moreover, the formal derived completions are equivalent to the classical formal completions (see 2.5). We thus recover the classical pro-cdh descent statement as formulated (for $K$-theory) for example in [KST18, Thm. A].
Proof of Theorem 4.6. We first prove the theorem under the additional assumption that $Y$ carries an $f$-ample line bundle. Exactly as in the proof of Proposition 4.2 we reduce to the case that $X$ is affine. Then $Y$ carries an ample line bundle.

By Theorem 3.2, we find an lafp $U$-modification $g: Y^{\prime} \rightarrow Y$ such that $f \circ g$ factors as an lafp, closed $U$-modification $h: Y^{\prime} \hookrightarrow \widetilde{X}$ followed by a derived blowup $p: \widetilde{X} \rightarrow X$ with center set-theoretically contained in $Z$. Both of these are isomorphisms over $U$. By Proposition 4.1 and Proposition 4.2, the maps of relative $E$-theory pro-spectra

$$
E\left(X, X_{Z}^{\wedge}\right) \rightarrow E\left(\widetilde{X}, \widetilde{X}_{Z}^{\wedge}\right) \rightarrow E\left(Y^{\prime}, Y^{\prime \wedge}{ }_{Z}^{\wedge}\right)
$$

are weak equivalences. Hence also the composite

$$
E\left(X, X_{Z}^{\wedge}\right) \rightarrow E\left(Y, Y_{Z}^{\wedge}\right) \rightarrow E\left(Y^{\prime}, Y^{\prime \wedge}{ }_{Z}^{\wedge}\right)
$$

is a weak equivalence. It follows that $E\left(X, X_{Z}^{\wedge}\right) \rightarrow E\left(Y, Y_{Z}^{\wedge}\right)$ is the inclusion of a direct summand (in the weak sense). As $Y$ carries an ample line bundle, we can repeat this argument for the $U$-modification $Y^{\prime} \rightarrow Y$. So also the second map in (12) is the inclusion of a direct summand. It now follows that both maps are in fact weak equivalences.

We now prove the theorem for general $Y$. As before, we may assume that $X$ is affine. By Theorem 3.2 again, there exists an lafp $U$-modification $g: Y^{\prime} \rightarrow Y$ such that $Y^{\prime}$ carries an ample line bundle relative to $X$. As $X$ is affine, this line bundle is in fact ample and it is also ample relative to $Y$. Hence, by Step 1, the maps of pro-spectra $E\left(X, X_{Z}^{\wedge}\right) \rightarrow E\left(Y^{\prime}, Y^{\prime \wedge}{ }_{Z}^{\wedge}\right)$ and $E\left(Y, Y_{Z}^{\wedge}\right) \rightarrow E\left(Y^{\prime}, Y^{\prime \wedge}{ }_{Z}^{\wedge}\right)$ both are weak equivalences. By 3 -for-2, also $E\left(X, X_{Z}^{\wedge}\right) \rightarrow E\left(Y, Y_{Z}^{\wedge}\right)$ is a weak equivalence, as desired.

# 5. Pro-Cdh descent for the Cotangent COMPlex and motivic COHOMOLOGy 

We fix some base ring $k$ (e.g., $k=\mathbb{Z}$ ). For $X$ a qcqs derived $k$-scheme, we denote by $L_{X} \in \operatorname{QCoh}(X)$ its (algebraic) cotangent complex relative to $k$, and by $L_{X}^{i}$ its $i$-th derived exterior power $(i \geq 0)$. If $X=\operatorname{Spec}(A)$ is affine, we also write $L_{A}^{i}$ for the $A$-module $\Gamma\left(X, L_{X}^{i}\right)$ corresponding to $L_{X}^{i}$. If $Y \rightarrow X$ is a morphism of qcqs derived $k$-schemes, we denote by

$L_{Y / X}$ its relative cotangent complex and by $L_{Y / X}^{\prime}$ its derived exterior powers. Similarly for a morphism of derived $k$-algebras $A \rightarrow B$.

If $Z \subseteq|X|$ is a closed subset with quasi-compact open complement, we obtain a procompletion along $Z$ functor

$$
(-)_{Z}^{\wedge}: \operatorname{QCoh}(X) \rightarrow \operatorname{Pro}(\operatorname{QCoh}(X))
$$

by pulling back to the ind-derived scheme $X_{Z}^{\wedge}$ and pushing forward. The usual formal completion along $Z$ is given by composing the above functor with $\lim : \operatorname{Pro}(\mathrm{QCoh}(X)) \rightarrow \mathrm{QCoh}(X)$.
Lemma 5.1. Let $X=\operatorname{Spec}(A)$ be an affine derived $k$-scheme, $Z \subseteq|X|$ a closed subset with quasi-compact open complement. Let $M \in \operatorname{Mod}(A$ on $Z)^{\text {aperf }}$ be an almost perfect $A$-module supported on $Z$. Then the canonical map

$$
M \rightarrow M_{Z}^{\wedge}
$$

is a weak equivalence in $\operatorname{Pro}(\operatorname{Mod}(A))$.
Proof. This was proven in the proof of Proposition 4.2 (replace $J$ there by $M$ ).
For a pro-system of derived rings $\{A(\alpha)\}_{\alpha}$ we denote by $\operatorname{Pro}(\operatorname{Mod})(\{A(\alpha)\})$ the $\infty$-category of pro-systems of modules over the pro-ring $\{A(\alpha)\}_{\alpha}$ (see [LT19, §2.4] for a precise definition).
Lemma 5.2. In the situation of the previous lemma, choose $f_{1}, \ldots, f_{r} \in \pi_{0}(A)$ defining $Z$, and write $A(\alpha)=A \nmid f_{1}^{\alpha}, \ldots, f_{r}^{\alpha}$. Then the pro-system

$$
\left\{L_{A(\alpha) / A}\right\}_{\alpha} \in \operatorname{Pro}(\operatorname{Mod})(\{A(\alpha)\})
$$

vanishes. In fact, all transition maps in this pro-system are null-homotopic.
Proof. This follows by base change from the universal case: Let $R=k\left[T_{1}, \ldots, T_{r}\right]$ be the polynomial ring over $k$, let $R \rightarrow k$ be the map sending all $T_{i}$ to 0 , and let $g_{\alpha}: R \rightarrow A$ be the map sending $T_{i}$ to $f_{i}^{\alpha}$. Then $A(\alpha)=k \otimes_{R, g_{\alpha}} A$ and consequently

$$
L_{A(\alpha) / A} \simeq L_{k / R} \otimes_{R, g_{\alpha}} A \simeq L_{k / R} \otimes_{k} A(\alpha)
$$

Consider the pro-system $\left\{L_{k / R}\right\}_{\alpha} \in \operatorname{Pro}(\operatorname{Mod}(k))$ whose transition maps are induced by the maps $R \rightarrow R$ sending the $T_{i}$ to $T_{i}^{\beta}$. Then

$$
\left\{L_{A(\alpha) / A}\right\}_{\alpha} \simeq\left\{L_{k / R}\right\}_{\alpha} \otimes_{k}\{A(\alpha)\}_{\alpha}
$$

Hence it suffices to prove that all transition maps $L_{k / R} \rightarrow L_{k / R}$ are null-homotopic in $\operatorname{Mod}(k)$. As $R \rightarrow k$ has a section, the transitivity triangle yields an equivalence $L_{k / R} \simeq \Sigma L_{R / k} \otimes_{R} k$. As $R$ is a polynomial ring, $L_{R / k}$ is discrete, given by the module of Kähler differentials $\Omega_{R / k}^{1}=\bigoplus_{i} R d T_{i}$. The map $T_{i} \mapsto T_{i}^{\beta}$ induces $d T_{i} \mapsto \beta T_{i}^{\beta-1} d T_{i}$ in $\Omega_{R / k}^{1}$, and hence the zero map in $\Omega_{R / k}^{1} \otimes_{R} k \simeq \Sigma^{-1} L_{k / R}$ for $\beta>1$. This proves our claim.
Lemma 5.3. In the situation of Lemma 5.2, the canonical map

$$
\left\{L_{A}^{i} \otimes_{A} A(\alpha)\right\}_{\alpha} \rightarrow\left\{L_{A(\alpha)}^{i}\right\}_{\alpha}
$$

is an equivalence in $\operatorname{Pro}(\operatorname{Mod})(\{A(\alpha)\})$.
Proof. The transitivity triangle for the maps $A \rightarrow A(\alpha)$ and Lemma 5.2 imply the case $i=1$. Passing to derived exterior powers over $\{A(\alpha)\}$ implies the general case.

The following theorem was suggested by Matthew Morrow. It generalizes [Mor16b, Thm. 2.4] (see also [EM23, Lemma 8.5]).

Theorem 5.4. Let $X$ be a qcqs derived $k$-scheme, $U \subseteq X$ a quasi-compact open subscheme, and denote by $Z$ the closed subset $X \backslash U$. Let $f: Y \rightarrow X$ be a locally almost finitely presented $U$-modification of $X$. Then for every $i \geq 0$, the square of pro-spectra (or pro-complexes)
![img-19.jpeg](img-19.jpeg)
is weakly cartesian.
Here, similarly as in the previous section, $\Gamma\left(X_{Z}^{\wedge}, L_{X_{Z}^{\wedge}}^{i}\right)$ denotes the pro-object $\left\{\Gamma\left(Z^{\prime}, L_{Z^{\prime}}^{i}\right)\right\}_{Z^{\prime} \hookrightarrow X}$ where $Z^{\prime} \hookrightarrow X$ runs through all closed immersions of derived schemes with $\left|Z^{\prime}\right|=Z$.
Proof. By Zariski descent we may assume that $X=\operatorname{Spec}(A)$ is affine. Choose $f_{1}, \ldots, f_{r} \in$ $\pi_{0}(A)$ defining $Z$, and write $A(\alpha)=A \nmid f_{1}^{\alpha}, \ldots, f_{r}^{\alpha}$ so that $X_{Z}^{\wedge}=\{\operatorname{Spec}(A(\alpha))\}_{\alpha \geq 1}$. Abusing notation slightly, we also write $f_{*} L_{Y}^{i} \in \operatorname{Mod}(A)$ for the module $\Gamma\left(X, f_{*} L_{Y}^{i}\right)=\Gamma\left(Y, L_{Y}^{i}\right)$ corresponding to $f_{*} L_{Y}^{i} \in \operatorname{QCoh}(X)$.

By Lemma 5.3 we have

$$
\Gamma\left(X_{Z}^{\wedge}, L_{X_{Z}^{\wedge}}^{i}\right) \simeq L_{A}^{i} \otimes_{A}\{A(\alpha)\}
$$

Similarly, using affine coverings of $Y$ and the usual induction we get

$$
\Gamma\left(Y_{Z}^{\wedge}, L_{Y_{Z}^{\wedge}}^{i}\right) \simeq\left(f_{*} L_{Y}^{i}\right) \otimes_{A}\{A(\alpha)\}
$$

So we have to prove that
![img-20.jpeg](img-20.jpeg)
is weakly cartesian. The map $L_{A}^{i} \rightarrow f_{*} L_{Y}^{i}$ factors as $L_{A}^{i} \rightarrow f_{*} f^{*} L_{A}^{i} \rightarrow f_{*} L_{Y}^{i}$, so it suffices to show that the two squares
![img-21.jpeg](img-21.jpeg)
are weakly cartesian.
We first treat the left one. Using the projection formula, we rewrite that square as the tensor product of $L_{A}^{i}$ with the square
![img-22.jpeg](img-22.jpeg)

As $f$ is lafp, $f_{*} \mathcal{O}_{Y}$ is almost perfect [Lur18, Thm. 5.6.0.2]. On the other hand, by assumption $A \rightarrow f_{*} \mathcal{O}_{Y}$ is an isomorphism outside $Z$. Hence the left vertical fibre in (16) lies in

$\operatorname{Mod}(A \text { on } Z)^{\text {aperf }}$. It now follows from Lemma 5.1 that the map on vertical fibres is a weak equivalence, and hence that (16) is weakly cartesian. As $L_{A}^{i}$ is connective, tensoring with $L_{A}^{i}$ preserves weak equivalences and weakly cartesian squares (see e.g. [LT19, Lemma 2.29]). Thus the left-hand square in (15) is weakly cartesian.

We now consider the right square in (15). The transitivity triangle for $f$ gives rise to a finite filtration on $L_{Y}^{i}$ whose graded pieces are given by

$$
f^{*} L_{X}^{k} \otimes_{\mathcal{O}_{Y}} L_{Y / X}^{i-k}, \quad k=0, \ldots, i
$$

It follows that the left vertical cofibre in our square has a finite filtration whose graded pieces are given by

$$
f_{*}\left(f^{*} L_{X}^{k} \otimes_{\mathcal{O}_{Y}} L_{Y / X}^{i-k}\right) \simeq L_{X}^{k} \otimes_{A} f_{*} L_{Y / X}^{i-k}, \quad k=0, \ldots, i-1
$$

As $f$ is lafp, the relative cotangent complex $L_{Y / X}$ is almost perfect [Lur04, Prop. 3.2.14] and so are its wedge powers $L_{Y / X}^{i-k}$. Again because $f$ is lafp, the direct images $f_{*} L_{Y / X}^{i-k}$ are almost perfect [Lur18, Thm. 5.6.0.2]. So we may again apply Lemma 5.1 to deduce that the map $f_{*} L_{Y / X}^{i-k} \rightarrow\left(f_{*} L_{Y / X}^{i-k}\right) \otimes_{A}\{A(\alpha)\}_{\alpha}$ is a weak equivalence for $k=0, \ldots, i-1$ and hence so is the map

L_{X}^{k} \otimes_{A} f_{*} L_{Y / X}^{i-k} \rightarrow\left(L_{X}^{k} \otimes_{A} f_{*} L_{Y / X}^{i-k}\right) \otimes_{A}\{A(\alpha)\}_{\alpha}

Using the above filtration, it follows that the map on vertical fibres in the right-hand square in (16) is a weak equivalence, and hence that square is also weakly cartesian. This finishes the proof of the theorem.
