# 6. Generalized Weibel vanishing 

In this section we prove our generalized Weibel vanishing result. As its formulation involves the valuative dimension, we start by recalling the latter (Subsection 6.1). In Subsection 6.2 we generalize some results about reductions of ideals from [HS06] to non-Noetherian rings. These will go into the proof of Weibel vanishing in Subsection 6.3.

6.1. Valuative dimension. The valuative dimension of a commutative ring was introduced and studied by Jaffard [Jaffard 0 ; we refer to [EHIK20, §2.3] for an account and to [KS24, Lemma 7.2] which reproves some of Jaffard's key results in modern language. For an integral domain $A$, it is defined as

$$
\operatorname{vdim}(A)=\sup \left\{n \mid \exists A \subseteq V_{0} \subsetneq V_{1} \subsetneq \cdots \subsetneq V_{n} \subseteq \operatorname{Frac}(A), V_{i} \text { valuation ring }\right\}
$$

and in general as $\operatorname{vdim}(A)=\sup \{\operatorname{vdim}(A / \mathfrak{p}) \mid \mathfrak{p} \in \operatorname{Spec}(A)\}$. For a classical scheme $X$, one then sets

$$
\operatorname{vdim}(X)=\sup \left\{\operatorname{vdim}\left(\mathcal{O}_{X}(U)\right) \mid U \subseteq X \text { affine open }\right\}
$$

We remark that that $\operatorname{vdim}(X)=\sup \operatorname{dim} \operatorname{RZ}\left(X_{\lambda}\right)$ is the supremum of the Krull dimensions of the Riemann-Zariski spaces as $X_{\lambda}$ ranges over the irreducible components of $X$. That is, the supremum of the Krull dimensions of all blowups (of finite type) of all $X_{\lambda}$. We always have $\operatorname{dim}(X) \leq \operatorname{vdim}(X)$ and equality holds if $X$ is Noetherian [Jaffard, Ch. IV, Thm. 1, Cor. 2 of Thm. 5]. Note that the valuative dimension only depends on the underlying reduced scheme of a scheme. In particular, it makes sense to talk about the valuative dimension of a closed subset of a scheme, by equipping it with any closed subscheme structure.

Let now $X$ be a derived or spectral scheme. The Krull dimension $\operatorname{dim}(X)$ of $X$ is defined to be the Krull dimension of the underlying topological space of $X$. The valuative dimension $\operatorname{vdim}(X)$ is defined to be the valuative dimension of the underlying classical scheme ${ }^{\mathrm{cl}} X$.

We will need the following result.
Lemma 6.1. For a scheme $X$ and a point $x \in X$ with closure $\overline{\{x\}}$ in $X$,

$$
\operatorname{vdim}\left(\mathcal{O}_{X, x}\right)+\operatorname{vdim}(\overline{\{x\}}) \leq \operatorname{vdim}(X)
$$

In particular,

$$
\operatorname{vdim}\left(\mathcal{O}_{X, x}\right)+\operatorname{dim}(\overline{\{x\}}) \leq \operatorname{vdim}(X)
$$

Proof. By definition it suffices to prove the lemma in case $X=\operatorname{Spec}(A)$ with $A$ integral. In this case, the first assertion is [Jaffard, Ch. IV, Prop. 2]; indeed, this follows from the basic facts that for any field extension $L / K$ any valuation $R \subseteq K$ admits at least one extension $S \subseteq L$, and $\operatorname{Spec}(S) \rightarrow \operatorname{Spec}(R)$ is always surjective. The second assertion follows from the fact that $\operatorname{dim}(Y) \leq \operatorname{vdim}(Y)$ for every scheme $Y$.
6.2. Reductions. Let $R$ be a ring, and let $J \subseteq I$ be ideals in $R$. Then $J$ is called a reduction of $I$ if there is a positive integer $n$ such that $J I^{n}=I^{n+1}$. Associated with an ideal $I$ we have its Rees algebra

$$
R[I t]=\sum_{n \geq 0} I^{n} t^{n} \subseteq R[t], \quad R[I t] \cong \bigoplus_{n \geq 0} I^{n}
$$

and its extended Rees algebra

$$
R\left[I t, t^{-1}\right]=\sum_{n<0} R t^{n}+\sum_{n \geq 0} I^{n} t^{n} \subseteq R\left[t, t^{-1}\right]
$$

So $\operatorname{Proj}(R[I t])$ is the blowup of $\operatorname{Spec}(R)$ in $\operatorname{Spec}(R / I)$, and $\operatorname{Spec}\left(R\left[I t, t^{-1}\right]\right)$ is a flat deformation of $\operatorname{Spec}(R)$ to the normal cone $\operatorname{Spec}\left(\bigoplus_{n \geq 0} I^{n} / I^{n+1}\right)$.
Lemma 6.2. Assume that $J \subseteq I$ are ideals in $R$.
(1) If $I$ is finitely generated, and $J$ is a reduction of $I$, then the ring extension $R[J t] \subseteq$ $R[I t]$ is finite.
(2) Conversely, if the ring extension $R[J t] \subseteq R[I t]$ is finite, then $J$ is a reduction of $I$.

Proof. This is [HS06, Th. 8.2.1] which is formulated for ideals in Noetherian rings. The proof given there works verbatim in the asserted generality.

Let $R$ be a local ring with maximal ideal $\mathfrak{m}$ and residue field $\kappa$. Let $I \subset R$ be a finitely generated, proper ideal. Then the fibre cone

$$
\mathcal{F}_{I}(R)=R[I t] \otimes_{R}^{\mathbb{C}} \kappa=\kappa \oplus I / \mathfrak{m} I \oplus I^{2} / \mathfrak{m} I^{2} \oplus \ldots
$$

is a finitely generated $\kappa$-algebra and in particular Noetherian. Its Krull dimension $\ell(I):=$ $\operatorname{dim} \mathcal{F}_{I}(R)$ is called the analytic spread of $I$.

Proposition 6.3. Let $R$ be a local ring, $I \subseteq R$ a finitely generated, proper ideal. Then the analytic spread of $I$ is bounded by the valuative dimension of $R$ :

$$
\ell(I) \leq \operatorname{vdim}(R)
$$

Proof. This proof follows [HS06, Prop. 5.1.6], which treats the Noetherian case. We may assume that $\operatorname{vdim}(R)$ is finite. Let $\operatorname{gr}_{I}(R)=R[I t] \otimes_{R}^{\mathbb{C}} R / I=R / I \oplus I / I^{2} \oplus \cdots=R\left[I t, t^{-1}\right] /\left(t^{-1}\right)$. As $\mathcal{F}_{I}(R)$ is a quotient of $\operatorname{gr}_{I}(R)$ and $\mathcal{F}_{I}(R)$ is Noetherian, we have

$$
\ell(I)=\operatorname{vdim} \mathcal{F}_{I}(R) \leq \operatorname{vdim} \operatorname{gr}_{I}(R)
$$

As $t^{-1}$ is a non-zero divisor in $R\left[I t, t^{-1}\right]$, it is not contained in any minimal prime ideal of $R\left[I t, t^{-1}\right]$. Thus $\operatorname{vdim} \operatorname{gr}_{I}(R) \leq \operatorname{vdim} R\left[I t, t^{-1}\right]-1$ by [EHIK20, Prop. 2.3.2(4)]. We claim that $\operatorname{vdim} R\left[I t, t^{-1}\right]=\operatorname{vdim} R+1$. This will finish the proof. To prove the claim, as the minimal prime ideals of $R\left[I t, t^{-1}\right]$ are in bijection with those of $R$ (see the general discussion in [HS06] before Thm. 5.1.4), we may assume that $R$ is a domain. As $\operatorname{Frac}\left(R\left[I t, t^{-1}\right]\right)=\operatorname{Frac}(R)(t)$ has transcendence degree 1 over $\operatorname{Frac}(R)$, [Jaf60, Ch. I, Thm. 2, p. 10] implies that if $v^{\prime}$ is any valuation of $\operatorname{Frac}\left(R\left[I t, t^{-1}\right]\right)$ extending a valuation $v$ of $\operatorname{Frac}(R)$ then the rank $\operatorname{rank}\left(v^{\prime}\right)$ of $v^{\prime}$ is at most $\operatorname{rank}(v)+1$. It follows that $\operatorname{vdim} R\left[I t, t^{-1}\right] \leq \operatorname{vdim} R+1$. The kernel of the surjection $R\left[I t, t^{-1}\right] \rightarrow R, t \mapsto 1$, is a non-trivial prime ideal, hence $\operatorname{vdim} R\left[I t, t^{-1}\right]>\operatorname{vdim} R$, for example by Lemma 6.1.

Proposition 6.4. Let $R$ be a local ring and $I \subseteq R$ be a finitely generated, proper ideal with analytic spread $\ell(I)$. Then there exists an $n \geq 1$ and a reduction $J$ of $I^{n}$ which is generated by $\ell(I)$ elements.

Proof. We follow the proof of [HS06, Prop. 8.3.8]. Let $\mathfrak{m}$ denote the maximal ideal of $R, \kappa=R / \mathfrak{m}$. By graded Noether normalization (see e.g. [HS06, Thm. 4.2.3]) there exists an integer $n$ and homogeneous elements $\bar{a}_{1}, \ldots, \bar{a}_{\ell} \in \mathcal{F}_{I}(R)_{n}=I^{n} / \mathfrak{m} I^{n}$ such that $A=\kappa\left[\bar{a}_{1}, \ldots, \bar{a}_{\ell}\right] \subseteq \mathcal{F}_{I}(R)$ is a polynomial ring and the extension $A \subseteq \mathcal{F}_{I}(R)$ is finite. In particular, $\ell=\operatorname{dim} \mathcal{F}_{I}(R)=\ell(I)$. Moreover, also the subextension $A \subseteq \bigoplus_{k \geq 0} I^{n k} / \mathfrak{m} I^{n k}$ is then finite (up to grading, the latter algebra is $\mathcal{F}_{I^{n}}(R)$ ). Let $n d$ be the maximal degree of a finite set of homogeneous generators. Then $I^{n(d+1)} / \mathfrak{m} I^{n(d+1)}=\sum_{i=1}^{\ell} \bar{a}_{i} \cdot I^{n d} / \mathfrak{m} I^{n d}$. Choose lifts $a_{i} \in I^{n}$ of the $\bar{a}_{i}$ and let $J=\left(a_{1}, \ldots, a_{\ell}\right) \subseteq I^{n}$. The previous equality implies $J I^{n d}+\mathfrak{m} I^{n(d+1)}=I^{n(d+1)}$. As $I$ is finitely generated, the Nakayama lemma gives $J I^{n d}=I^{n(d+1)}$, i.e. $J$ is a reduction of $I^{n}$.
6.3. Weibel vanishing. The following theorem generalizes [KST18, Thm. B], which treats the case of Noetherian classical schemes.

Theorem 6.5. Let $X$ be a qcqs spectral scheme. Then the following hold.
(1) $K_{-i}(X)=0$ for all $i>\operatorname{vdim}(X)$.

(2) For all $i \geq \operatorname{vdim}(X)$ and any integer $r \geq 0$, the pullback map $K_{-i}(X) \rightarrow K_{-i}\left(\mathbb{A}_{X}^{r}\right)$ is an isomorphism.

In the spectral setting, the affine space in (2) is either the flat one or the smooth one, the assertion holds for both. In fact, one reduces immediately to underlying classical schemes (see the beginning of the proof in Subsection 6.5), and in both cases this is just the classical affine space.

The proof of Theorem 6.5 is along the lines of Kerz's proof in the Noetherian case in [Ker18] which is a bit more direct than the one in [KST18, Thm. B]. It uses the theory of reductions presented in Subsection 6.2 in order to prove better descent results for blowups. The following lemma replaces [KS17, Lemma 4] and is essentially due to Scheiderer [Sch92].

Lemma 6.6. Let $X$ be a spectral space, and $\mathcal{F}$ a sheaf of abelian groups on $X$. Let $r \geq 0$ be an integer. Assume that $\mathcal{F}_{y}=0$ for all points $y \in X$ with $\operatorname{dim}(\overline{\{y\}})>r$. Then $H^{n}(X, \mathcal{F})=0$ for all integers $n>r$.

Proof. This is a direct consequence of results of Scheiderer [Sch92], see the proof of Proposition 4.7 there. Let $\operatorname{sp}_{\bullet}(X) \rightarrow X$ be the quasi-augmented simplicial topological space defined in [Sch92, §2]: Its set of $n$-simplices is given by chains of specialisations

$$
x_{0} \succ \cdots \succ x_{n}
$$

of points in $X$ with coincidences between the $x_{i}$ allowed. The topology is induced by the constructible topology on $X^{n+1}$. The quasi-augmentation is given by the canonical map $\operatorname{sp}_{0}(X) \rightarrow X$. Let $\gamma_{n}: \operatorname{sp}_{n}(X) \rightarrow X$ be the map sending a chain as above to $x_{0}$. By [Sch92, Rem. 2.5 and Thm. 4.1], the cohomology groups $H^{*}(X, \mathcal{F})$ are computed by the complex

$$
\Gamma\left(\operatorname{sp}_{0}(X), \gamma_{0}^{*} \mathcal{F}\right) \rightarrow \Gamma\left(\operatorname{sp}_{1}(X), \gamma_{1}^{*} \mathcal{F}\right) \rightarrow \Gamma\left(\operatorname{sp}_{2}(X), \gamma_{2}^{*} \mathcal{F}\right) \rightarrow \cdots
$$

which arises from the cosimplicial abelian group $[n] \rightarrow \Gamma\left(\operatorname{sp}_{n}(X), \gamma_{n}^{*} \mathcal{F}\right)$. Let

$$
B_{0} \rightarrow B_{1} \rightarrow B_{2} \rightarrow \cdots
$$

be the associated normalized subcomplex, which also computes $H^{*}(X, \mathcal{F})$. As in the proof of [Sch92, Prop. 4.7], $B_{n}$ coincides with the group of those sections $a \in \Gamma\left(\operatorname{sp}_{n}(X), \gamma_{n}^{*} \mathcal{F}\right)$ whose supports consist only of non-degenerate simplices $x \in \operatorname{sp}_{n}(X)$. Hence, it suffices to show $\left(\gamma_{n}^{*} \mathcal{F}\right)_{x}=0$ for such $x$ if $n>r$. So let now $x \in \operatorname{sp}_{n}(X)$ be given by a chain of specialisations $x_{0} \succ \cdots \succ x_{n}$ with pairwise different $x_{i}$ 's. Then, we must have $\operatorname{dim}\left(\overline{\left\{x_{0}\right\}}\right) \geq n>r$. Thus the assumption implies $\left(\gamma_{n}^{*} \mathcal{F}\right)_{x}=\mathcal{F}_{x_{0}}=0$ as wanted. This completes the proof of the lemma.

Lemma 6.7. Let $X$ be a qcqs spectral scheme of finite valuative dimension. Let $F$ be a sheaf of spectra on $X$ for the Zariski topology. Assume that for every $x \in X$, the homotopy groups of the stalks $\pi_{-i}\left(F_{x}\right)$ vanish for $i>\operatorname{vdim}\left(\mathcal{O}_{X, x}\right)$. Then $\pi_{-i}(F(X))=0$ for all $i>\operatorname{vdim}(X)$.

Note that if $F$ is $K$-theory, then $\pi_{-i}\left(K_{x}\right) \cong K_{-i}\left(\mathcal{O}_{X, x}\right)$ as $K$-theory commutes with filtered colimits.

Proof. This is deduced from Lemma 6.6 by the same argument as the proof of [KS17, Prop. 3]. From [CM21, Thm. 3.12] we know that the homotopy dimension of $X_{\text {Zar }}$ is bounded by the Krull dimension $\operatorname{dim}(X)$, and in particular the $\infty$-topos of sheaves of spaces on $X_{\text {Zar }}$ is hypercomplete. Hence there is a convergent Zariski descent spectral sequence

$$
E_{2}^{p, q}=H^{p}\left(X, \widetilde{F}_{-q}\right) \Longrightarrow \pi_{-p-q}(F(X))
$$

where $\widetilde{F}_{-q}$ is the Zariski sheaf of abelian groups on $X$ associated to the presheaf $U \mapsto$ $\pi_{-q}(F(U))$, and $E_{2}^{p, *}=0$ unless $0 \leq p \leq \operatorname{dim}(X)$. It suffices to show $E_{2}^{p, q}=0$ for $p+q>\operatorname{vdim}(X)$. We may assume $p \leq \operatorname{dim}(X)$ so that $q>0$. Note that $\widetilde{F}_{-q, x}=\pi_{-q}\left(F_{x}\right)$. By Lemma 6.6 it now suffices to check that $\pi_{-q}\left(F_{x}\right)=0$ for all points $x$ with $\operatorname{dim}(\overline{\{x\}})>$ $\operatorname{vdim}(X)-q$. But for such points $x$ we have

$$
\operatorname{vdim}\left(\mathcal{O}_{X, x}\right) \leq \operatorname{vdim}(X)-\operatorname{dim}(\overline{\{x\}})<q
$$

by Lemma 6.1, and hence $\pi_{-q}\left(F_{x}\right)=0$ by assumption.
6.4. $K$-theoretic preparations. In the proof of Theorem 6.5, we use the following well known facts about non-positive $K$-theory on affine (derived) schemes.
Lemma 6.8. (1) Let $A$ be a derived ring. Then the canonical map $K(A) \rightarrow K\left(\pi_{0}(A)\right)$ is 2-connective, i.e. it induces an isomorphism on $\pi_{i}$ for $i \leq 1$ and a surjection on $\pi_{2}$.
(2) Let $A$ be a discrete commutative ring, and let $I \subseteq A$ be a locally nilpotent ideal (i.e., every element of $I$ is nilpotent). Then the map $K(A) \rightarrow K(A / I)$ is 1-connective.
(3) Let $A$ be a discrete, commutative ring, $X=\operatorname{Spec}(A)$, and let $X=X_{1} \cup X_{2}$ be a closed covering of $X$. Write $X_{12}=X_{1} \cap X_{2}$. Then there is a long exact sequence

$$
K_{1}(X) \rightarrow K_{1}\left(X_{1}\right) \oplus K_{1}\left(X_{2}\right) \rightarrow K_{1}\left(X_{12}\right) \rightarrow K_{0}(X) \rightarrow \ldots
$$

Proof. (1) For connective $K$-theory, this is due to Waldhausen [Wal78, Prop. 1.1]. The general case follows from this together with [BGT13, Thm. 9.53] (or [KST18, Thm. 2.16]). Alternatively, see [LT19, Lemma 2.4] for a slightly more general statement.
(2) Writing $I$ as a filtered colimit of nilpotent ideals, we may assume that $I$ itself is nilpotent. Then $K_{0}(I)=0$ by [Wei13, Exc. II.2.5] and hence $K_{1}(A) \rightarrow K_{1}(A / I)$ is surjective by Prop. III.2.3 there. Moreover, $K_{0}(A) \rightarrow K_{0}(A / I)$ is an isomorphism by [Wei13, Lemma II.2.2]. As the ideal generated by $I$ in any $A$-algebra is still nilpotent, it then follows from the definition of negative $K$-groups [Wei13, Def. III.4.1] that $K_{i}(A) \rightarrow K_{i}(A / I)$ is an isomorphism for all $i \leq 0$.
(3) Let $I$ and $J$ be the ideals defining $X_{1}$ and $X_{2}$, respectively. Hence $X_{12}=\operatorname{Spec}(A / I+J)$. Let $A^{\prime}=A / I \cap J$. Then $A^{\prime}$ sits in a Milnor square
![img-24.jpeg](img-24.jpeg)

Hence, by [Wei13, Thm. III.4.3], there is a long exact sequence

$$
K_{1}\left(A^{\prime}\right) \rightarrow K_{1}(A / I) \oplus K_{1}(A / J) \rightarrow K_{1}(A / I+J) \rightarrow K_{0}\left(A^{\prime}\right) \rightarrow \ldots
$$

As $X_{1} \cup X_{2}=X$, the ideal $I \cap J$ is contained in the nilradical of $A$ and so is locally nilpotent. Using (2), we may thus replace $A^{\prime}$ by $A$ in the above sequence to get a long exact sequence of the statement.

The previous lemma has as a simple consequence the following lemma which will allow us to get some control on the negative $K$-theory of certain blowups in Proposition 6.12.
Lemma 6.9. Let $X$ be a separated derived scheme admitting a covering by $\ell$ affine open subschemes. Then the canonical morphism

$$
K(X) \rightarrow K\left({ }^{\mathrm{cl}} X^{\prime}\right)
$$

where ${ }^{\mathrm{cl}} X^{\prime}$ denotes ${ }^{\mathrm{cl}} X$ with any closed subscheme structure between ${ }^{\mathrm{cl}} X^{\text {red }}$ and ${ }^{\mathrm{cl}} X$, is $(-\ell+$ 2)-connective.

Proof. Induction on $\ell$. If $\ell=1$, this is Lemma $6.8(1,2)$. For $\ell>1$ write $X=V \cup U$ with $U$ affine and $V$ admitting an open covering by $\ell-1$ affines. As $X$ is separated, also $V \cap U$ has an open covering by $\ell-1$ affines. The claim follows from the inductive hypothesis by considering the map from the cartesian square
![img-25.jpeg](img-25.jpeg)
to the similar cartesian square with the underlying classical schemes with the subscheme structure induced from $X^{\prime}$.

In the following, if $X$ is a qcqs derived scheme and $Z \hookrightarrow X$ is a derived subscheme, we denote by $K(X, Z)$ the relative $K$-theory $\operatorname{fib}(K(X) \rightarrow K(Z))$.

Lemma 6.10. Let $X, Y$ be quasi-compact, separated classical schemes, $Z \hookrightarrow X$ a classically finitely presented closed subscheme. Let $f: Y \rightarrow X$ be a finite morphism which is an isomorphism outside $Z$. Assume that $X$ has a covering by $\ell$ affine open subschemes. Then the canonical map

$$
K(X, Z) \rightarrow K\left(Y, f^{-1}(Z)\right)
$$

is $(-\ell+1)$-connective.
Proof. By induction on $\ell$, as in the proof of Lemma 6.9, it suffices to treat the case $\ell=1$, i.e. $X$ and hence $Y$ affine. As $K$-theory commutes with filtered colimits, by Lemma 6.11 below we may assume that $f: Y \rightarrow X$ is finitely presented. By Remark 4.3 the square of pro-spectra
![img-26.jpeg](img-26.jpeg)
is then weakly cartesian. Hence the square of spectra obtained by applying $\lim : \operatorname{Pro}(\mathrm{Sp}) \rightarrow$ Sp,
![img-27.jpeg](img-27.jpeg)
is cartesian. By Lemma $6.8(1,2)$, each transition map in the pro-spectrum $K\left(X_{Z}^{\wedge}\right)$ is 1connective. In particular, using the Milnor sequence we get isomorphisms $\pi_{0}\left(\lim K\left(X_{Z}^{\wedge}\right)\right) \cong$ $\lim K_{0}\left(X_{Z}^{\wedge}\right) \cong K_{0}(Z)$ and surjections $\pi_{1}\left(\lim K\left(X_{Z}^{\wedge}\right)\right) \rightarrow \lim K_{1}\left(X_{Z}^{\wedge}\right) \rightarrow K_{1}(Z)$. In other words, $\lim K\left(X_{Z}^{\wedge}\right) \rightarrow K(Z)$ is 1 -connective. Consider the following diagram in which the left

vertical map is an equivalence by the previous cartesian square.

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \operatorname{fib}(K(X) \rightarrow \lim K\left(X_{Z}^{\wedge}\right)) \longrightarrow K(X, Z) \\
& \downarrow \simeq \\
& \operatorname{fib}\left(K(Y) \rightarrow \lim K\left(Y_{Z}^{\wedge}\right)\right) \longrightarrow K\left(Y, f^{-1}(Z)\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

The fibre of the top horizontal map identifies with $\Omega \operatorname{fib}\left(\lim K\left(X_{Z}^{\wedge}\right) \rightarrow K(Z)\right)$ and is hence 0 -connective. By the same arguments, the lower horizontal map is 0 -connective. It follows that also the right vertical map is 0 -connective.

Lemma 6.11. Let $\varphi: A \rightarrow B$ be a finite morphism of rings such that $\operatorname{Spec}(\varphi): \operatorname{Spec}(B) \rightarrow$ $\operatorname{Spec}(A)$ is an isomorphism outside $V(I)$ where $I=\left(f_{1}, \ldots, f_{r}\right) \subseteq A$. Then we can write $\varphi$ as a filtered colimit of finitely presented, finite maps $\varphi_{\lambda}: A \rightarrow B_{\lambda}$ such that each $\operatorname{Spec}\left(\varphi_{\lambda}\right)$ is an isomorphism outside $V(I)$.

Proof. Choose $A$-module generators $b_{1}, \ldots, b_{s}$ of $B$. We get a surjection $A\left[T_{1}, \ldots, T_{s}\right] \rightarrow B$, $T_{i} \mapsto b_{i}$. Let $J$ denote its kernel. As $b_{i}$ is integral over $A$, there exists a monic polynomial $p_{i} \in A[X]$ with $p_{i}\left(b_{i}\right)=0$. Clearly, $p_{i}\left(T_{i}\right) \in J$.

Let $f$ be one of the generators $f_{j}$ of $I$. As $\operatorname{Spec}(\varphi)$ is an isomorphism outside $V(I)$, we have $A\left[f^{-1}\right] \xrightarrow{\simeq} B\left[f^{-1}\right]$. In particular, $B\left[f^{-1}\right]$ is finitely presented as an $A\left[f^{-1}\right]$-algebra, and it follows that $J\left[f^{-1}\right] \subseteq A\left[f^{-1}\right]\left[T_{1}, \ldots, T_{s}\right]$ is a finitely generated ideal. We may pick finitely many generators $q_{j k}$ which already live in $J$.

Now write $J$ as increasing union of finitely generated ideals $J_{\lambda}$ where each $J_{\lambda}$ contains all the $p_{i}\left(T_{i}\right)$ and all $q_{j k}$ 's. By construction, $B_{\lambda}=A\left[T_{1}, \ldots, T_{s}\right] / J_{\lambda}$ is then finitely presented over $A$, finite (as in $B_{\lambda}$ each $T_{i}$ is integral over $A$ ), and $\operatorname{Spec}\left(B_{\lambda}\right) \rightarrow \operatorname{Spec}(A)$ is an isomorphism outside $V(I)$ (as $J_{\lambda}\left[f_{j}^{-1}\right]=J\left[f_{j}^{-1}\right]$ for all $\left.j\right)$. Clearly, $\operatorname{colim}_{\lambda} B_{\lambda}=B$.

Proposition 6.12. Let $R$ be a local ring, $I \subseteq R$ be a finitely generated, proper ideal of analytic spread $\ell=\ell(I)$. Let $Z=V(I), f: \mathrm{Bl}_{Z}(X) \rightarrow X$ the blowup, and $E=f^{-1}(Z)$ the classical exceptional divisor. Then the pullback map

$$
K(X, Z) \rightarrow K\left(\operatorname{Bl}_{Z}(X), E\right)
$$

is $(-\ell+1)$-connective. More generally, for any $r \geq 0$, the pullback map

$$
K\left(\mathbb{A}^{r} \times X, \mathbb{A}^{r} \times Z\right) \rightarrow K\left(\mathbb{A}^{r} \times \mathrm{Bl}_{Z}(X), \mathbb{A}^{r} \times E\right)
$$

is $(-\ell+1)$-connective.
Proof. By Proposition 6.4, there exists a reduction $J$ of some power $I^{n}$ of $I$ generated by $\ell$ elements, say $J=\left(f_{1}, \ldots, f_{\ell}\right)$. As $\mathrm{Bl}_{I^{n}}(R)=\mathrm{Bl}_{I}(R)$ canonically, Lemma 6.2 yields a finite $X$-morphism $\operatorname{Bl}_{Z}(X)=\operatorname{Bl}_{I}(R) \rightarrow \operatorname{Bl}_{J}(R)$. Let $\widetilde{X}$ be the derived blowup of $X$ in $f_{1}, \ldots, f_{\ell}$. Then we have a closed immersion $\mathrm{Bl}_{J}(R) \hookrightarrow \widetilde{X}$ and in total a finite morphism $\mathrm{Bl}_{I}(X) \rightarrow \widetilde{X}$. Moreover, $\widetilde{X}$ has a covering by $\ell$ affine open subschemes. Write $D={ }^{\mathrm{cl}}\left(\widetilde{X} \times_{X} Z\right)$. We now argue similarly as in the proof of Lemma 6.10. Consider the following commutative diagram.
![img-28.jpeg](img-28.jpeg)

The left vertical map is an equivalence by Proposition 4.1 (note that $|Z|=|V(J)|$ ). The top horizontal map is 0 -connective, the lower horizontal map is $(-\ell+1)$-connective by Lemma 6.9. Hence the right vertical map is $(-\ell+1)$-connective. Using Lemma 6.9 again, we see that $K(\widetilde{X}, D) \rightarrow K\binom{c^{i} \widetilde{X}, D}{c^{i} \widetilde{X}, D}$ is $(-\ell+2)$-connective. In total, $K(X, Z) \rightarrow K\binom{c^{i} \widetilde{X}}{X}, D$ is $(-\ell+1)$ connective. ${ }^{5}$ By Lemma 6.10, the map $K\binom{c^{i} \widetilde{X}}{X}, D) \rightarrow K\left(\mathrm{Bl}_{Z}(X), E\right)$ is $(-\ell+1)$-connective. Hence the composite is $(-\ell+1)$-connective, as asserted.

The more general claim can be proved by exactly the same argument, using that $\mathbb{A}^{r}$ is affine and flat over $\mathbb{Z}$ and derived blowups commute with arbitrary base change.

# 6.5. Proof of Weibel vanishing. 

Proof of Theorem 6.5. We write $N^{(r)} K(X)$ for the cofiber of the canonical split inclusion $K(X) \rightarrow K\left(\mathbb{A}_{X}^{r}\right)$ so that we have $K\left(\mathbb{A}_{X}^{r}\right) \cong K(X) \oplus N^{(r)} K(X)$. Then assertion (2) of the theorem is equivalent to the statement that $N^{(r)} K_{-i}(X)=0$ for all $i \geq \operatorname{vdim}(X)$.

We may assume that $d=\operatorname{vdim}(X)$ is finite and prove the theorem by induction on $d$. By Lemma 6.7, applied to $K$ and $\Sigma N^{(r)} K$ respectively, we may assume that $X$ is affine and local. In this case, $K_{-i}\left(\mathbb{A}_{X}^{r}\right) \cong K_{-i}\left(\mathbb{A}_{\mathrm{Crred}}^{r}\right)$ for all $i \geq 0$ and all $r \geq 0$ by Lemma 6.8 (1), (2). So we can assume that $X$ is a classical reduced affine local scheme.

If $d=0$, then also the Krull dimension $\operatorname{dim}(X)$ is 0 . As $X$ is local and reduced, it is the spectrum of a field. Hence $K_{-i}(X)=0$ and for all $i>0$ and $N^{(r)} K(X)=0$ (by [Wei13, Thm. II.7.8] and the definition of negative $K$-groups), as $X$ is regular Noetherian.

Now assume that $d$ is positive and the assertion is proven for all qcqs derived schemes that are of valuative dimension $<d$.
Claim. The assertion of Theorem 6.5 holds for $X$ as above under the additional assumption that $X$ is irreducible.
Proof of the claim. Write $X=\operatorname{Spec}(R)$. So $R$ is a local integral domain. Let $\gamma$ be an element in $K_{-i}(R)$ with $i>d$ or in $N^{(r)} K_{-i}(R) \subseteq K_{-i}\left(\mathbb{A}_{R}^{r}\right)$ with $i \geq d$ in case $r>0$. We have to show that $\gamma=0$.

As $K$-theory commutes with filtered colimits, there exists a subring $R_{0}$ of $R$, finitely generated as a $\mathbb{Z}$-algebra, and $\gamma_{0} \in K_{-i}\left(\mathbb{A}_{R_{0}}^{r}\right)$ pulling back to $\gamma$. By [KS17, Prop. 5], there exists a (finitely generated) ideal $I_{0} \subseteq R_{0}$ such that $\gamma_{0}$ is annihilated in $K_{-i}\left(\mathbb{A}^{r} \times \mathrm{Bl}_{I_{0}}\left(R_{0}\right)\right)$. Let $I=R I_{0} \subseteq R$, and $Z=V(I)$. By functoriality of the blowup, $\gamma$ is annihilated in $K_{-i}\left(\mathbb{A}^{r} \times \mathrm{Bl}_{Z}(X)\right)$. Let $E \subseteq \mathrm{Bl}_{Z}(X)$ denote the exceptional divisor. By construction $Z \subseteq X$ is a finitely presented, proper subscheme, hence $\operatorname{Bl}_{Z}(X) \rightarrow X$ is a modification and thus $\operatorname{vdim} \operatorname{Bl}_{Z}(X)=\operatorname{vdim} X=d$ [EHIK20, Prop. 2.3.2(6)]. Furthermore $\operatorname{vdim}(Z), \operatorname{vdim}(E)<d$ by loc. cit., Assertion 4.

We now treat the case of $\gamma \in K_{-i}(R)$ with $i>d$. Consider the commutative diagram of exact sequences
![img-29.jpeg](img-29.jpeg)

[^0]
[^0]:    ${ }^{5}$ In fact, using the above connectivity estimates, this follows more easily from the derived generalization of Thomason's theorem [Tho93] in [KST18, Thm. 3.7] which holds without any Noetherianity assumptions (with the same proof as in loc. cit.)

As $\operatorname{vdim}(Z), \operatorname{vdim}(E)<d$, the four outer groups vanish by induction. If $I=R$, then $\mathrm{Bl}_{\mathcal{Z}}(X)=X$ and hence $\gamma=0$. So we may now assume that $I \subset R$ is a proper ideal. By Proposition 6.3 we then have $\ell(I) \leq \operatorname{vdim}(R)=d$. As $i>d$, Proposition 6.12 implies that the second vertical map is an isomorphism. Hence $K_{-i}(X) \rightarrow K_{-i}\left(\operatorname{Bl}_{\mathcal{Z}}(X)\right)$ is an isomorphism, too, and hence $\gamma=0$.

The argument in the case $\gamma \in N^{(r)} K_{-i}(R)$ with $i \geq d$ is exactly the same with the $K$-groups above replaced by the $N^{(r)} K$-groups. This finishes the proof of the Claim.

We now consider the general case. So $X$ is now a classical, reduced, affine, local scheme of valuative dimension $d>0$. For ease of notation, we only consider assertion (1) of the theorem. The proof of (2) is completely parallel. To reduce to the integral case treated in the Claim above, we apply an argument from [EHIK20, Thm. 2.4.15] as follows: Take an integer $i>d=\operatorname{vdim}(X)$ and an element $\gamma \in K_{-i}(X)$. We wish to show that $\gamma=0$. Let

$$
\mathcal{E}=\left\{Z \hookrightarrow X \text { reduced, closed } \mid \gamma_{\mid Z} \neq 0 \in K_{-i}(Z)\right\}
$$

We need to prove that $\mathcal{E}=\emptyset$. Note that every $Z \in \mathcal{E}$ is itself a reduced local affine scheme and that $\mathcal{E}$ is ordered by inclusion. Let $\left(Z_{\lambda}\right)_{\lambda \in \Lambda}$ be a descending chain in $\mathcal{E}$ and put $Z=\lim _{\lambda \in \Lambda} Z_{\lambda}$. As $K$-theory commutes with filtered colimits of rings, we have $K_{-i}(Z)=\operatorname{colim}_{\lambda \in \Lambda} K_{-i}\left(Z_{\lambda}\right)$. So if $\gamma_{\mid Z}=0$, then there exists a $\lambda$ such that $\gamma_{\mid Z_{\lambda}}=0$, which is a contradiction. Hence $\gamma_{\mid Z} \neq 0$ so that $Z \in \mathcal{E}$ and $Z$ is a lower bound of $\left(Z_{\lambda}\right)_{\lambda \in \Lambda}$. If $\mathcal{E} \neq \emptyset$, we may apply Zorn's lemma to conclude that $\mathcal{E}$ has a minimal element $Z$. As $K_{-i}(Z) \neq 0, Z$ must be reducible. Let $Z^{\text {gen }}$ be the set of the generic points of $Z$ equipped with the induced topology from the underlying topological space of $Z$. By [HJ65, Cor. 2.4] (see also [EHIK20, Lemma 2.4.14]), there exists a decomposition $Z^{\text {gen }}=S_{1} \cup S_{2}$ with $S_{i}$ closed and non-empty for $i=1,2$. Letting $Z_{i}$ be the closure of $S_{i}$ in $Z$ with reduced scheme structure, we have $Z=Z_{1} \cup Z_{2}$ and $Z_{i} \cap Z^{\text {gen }}=S_{i}$ for $i=1,2$. In particular, $Z_{1} \cap Z_{2} \cap Z^{\text {gen }}=\emptyset$ so that $\operatorname{vdim}\left(Z_{1} \cap Z_{2}\right)<d$ by [EHIK20, Prop. 2.3.2(4)]. By excision in non-positive $K$-theory for closed coverings of affine schemes (Lemma 6.8(3)), we have an exact sequence

$$
K_{-i+1}\left(Z_{1} \cap Z_{2}\right) \rightarrow K_{-i}(Z) \rightarrow K_{-i}\left(Z_{1}\right) \oplus K_{-i}\left(Z_{2}\right)
$$

The group on the left-hand side vanishes by induction. As $Z$ was minimal in $\mathcal{E}$, we must have $\gamma_{\mid Z_{i}}=0$ for $i=1,2$. Thus we get $\gamma_{\mid Z}=0$, which is a contradiction. Thus we must have $\mathcal{E}=\emptyset$, which completes the proof of Theorem 6.5.

We now give a proof of Theorem 1.4, reproduced from [KM21, Rem. 3.5]. We refer to [EHIK20, §2.1] for a discussion of the cdh topology in this generality but note that the definition of the cdh topology used in [EHIK20] is the one used by Suslin and Voevodsky, [SV00, Def. 5.7], and the proof that cdh Čech descent is equivalent to cdh excision is Voevodsky's proof from [Voe10], rewritten in modern language in [AHW17, Thm. 3.2.5]. Voevodsky's proof that cdh Čech descent is equivalent to cdh hyperdescent requires Noetherian hypotheses that were lifted in [EHIK20].

Proof of Theorem 1.4. We note that homotopy $K$-theory is a cdh sheaf. This was first proven by Cisinski [Cis13] for Noetherian schemes of finite dimension (and in characteristic 0 previously by Haesemeyer [Hae04]), which implies the general statement by absolute Noetherian approximation; alternatively it follows from the fact that $K H$ is truncating, see [LT19, Cor. A.5]. In particular, we get the maps

$$
L_{\mathrm{cdh}} K_{\geq 0} \rightarrow L_{\mathrm{cdh}} K \rightarrow K H
$$

which we want to show are equivalences. By [EHIK20, Thm. 2.4.15, Cor. 2.3.3] the $\infty$-topos of cdh sheaves of spaces on finitely presented $X$-schemes is locally of finite homotopy dimension and of homotopy dimension $\leq \operatorname{vdim}(X)$. This implies that we get a convergent spectral sequence

$$
E_{2}^{p, q}=H^{p}\left(X_{\mathrm{cdh}}, \tilde{\pi}_{-q} K H\right) \Longrightarrow K H_{-p-q}(X)
$$

where $\tilde{\pi}_{q} K H$ denotes the cdh sheafified homotopy groups of $K H$. A conservative family of points for the cdh topology is given by the spectra of henselian valuation rings [GL01], [GK15, Thm. 2.3, Thm. 2.6], [EHIK20, Cor. 2.4.19]. As $K$-theory of valuation rings is connective and agrees with its homotopy $K$-theory [KM21, Thm. 3.4], [KST21, Lem. 4.3], and $K$ and $K H$ commute with filtered colimits, the maps (17) are equivalences so we get part (2) of Theorem 1.4. The vanishing

$$
K H_{-i}(X)=0, \quad \text { for all } i>\operatorname{vdim}(X)
$$

claimed in part (1) follows from the spectral sequence (18).

abstract:
We prove a `pro-cdh descent' result for suitably connective localizing
invariants and the cotangent complex on arbitrary qcqs derived schemes. As an
application, we deduce that the K-groups of arbitrary qcqs schemes vanish below
the negative of their valuative dimension.
